story: Created with Sketch.Activists seek to force vote at party's annual conference to give public a 'final say'&nbspon Britain leaving the EUClick to followIndy PoliticsLabour members launch plan to make Jeremy Corbyn back new referendum on final Brexit dealGrassroots Labour activists will attempt&nbspto force&nbspJeremy Corbyn to shift his Brexit stance by asking the party’s annual conference to back calls for a referendum on the final Brexit deal.They are calling on party members across the country to back&nbspa motion to “stop Tory Brexit” and commit Labour to holding a&nbsp“People’s Vote” on the final deal.&nbspIt comes as pressure for another referendum mounts and&nbspa petition in support of&nbspThe&nbspIndependent‘s Final Say campaign in favour of another public&nbspvote passed&nbsp580,000 signatures.The new grassroots campaign demands that Labour&nbspMPs and peers&nbspvote against the deal Theresa May negotiates with Brussels and instead push for a general election at which the party’s manifesto would promise another&nbspBrexit referendum.If attempts to force an election fail, the motion says, Labour should instead campaign for a People’s Vote.&nbspThe campaign is being organised by Labour for a People’s Vote, which hopes to force a vote on the motion at Labour’s&nbspannual conference in Liverpool in&nbspSeptember.The group said more than 130 constituency&nbspLabour parties (CLPs) across the country will discuss the&nbspmotion on Brexit and vote on whether they want to propose it for discussion at the conference. Some have already agreed to do so.Each CLP is allowed to propose one motion for discussion at conference, with those receiving the most support from delegates at the gathering likely to be put to a vote. The window for submitting motions opened today.The motion could become party policy if passed, but the Labour leadership is&nbsplikely to strongly resist attempts to force it to change tack.Last year, grassroots attempts to have Brexit debated by delegates at&nbspparty conference&nbspwere seen off by Mr Corbyn’s team and trade union Unite, who&nbspfeared they could force a change in party policy.The latest campaign was endorsed by a number of prominent Labour figures.Manuel&nbspCortes,&nbspgeneral secretary of the&nbspTSSA&nbsptrade union, said:&nbsp“Brexit is a Tory con trick for the benefit of the richest one per cent. It will rob workers and drive down wages. The wealthy chums of Boris,&nbspGove&nbspand Fox will line their over-filled pockets on the back of burning workers’ rights and attacking the rest of us.“It’s them – the ruling class of this country – that are to blame for the fact that their austerity has seen our living standards fall. Yet they have the gall to try and pin the blame on migrants for their class war which is making us poorer. Labour cannot collaborate with their Brexit agenda as it’s out of&nbspBannon’s&nbspfascist notebook”People's Vote march - demanding vote on final Brexit dealA young protestor shouts as she takes part in the People's Vote demonstration against Brexit Gina Miller and Caroline LucasTens of thousands of people march through LondonDemonstrators at the People's Vote March 'Two months too young to decide on my future'A young girl joins in the marchAn EU flag is draped across the statue of Winston Chruchill in Parliament SquareVince Cable MP, Pro-EU campaigner Gina Miller, Tony Robinson and Caroline Lucas MP join with crowds Crowds gather on Pall MallA man resembling Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, joins EU supportersPeople gather in Trafalgar Square Pro-EU campaigner Gina Miller and Tony RobinsonEU supporters, calling on the government to give Britons a vote on the final Brexit deal, participate in the 'People's Vote' marchA young protestor shouts as she takes part in the People's Vote demonstration against Brexit Gina Miller and Caroline LucasTens of thousands of people march through LondonDemonstrators at the People's Vote March 'Two months too young to decide on my future'A young girl joins in the marchAn EU flag is draped across the statue of Winston Chruchill in Parliament SquareVince Cable MP, Pro-EU campaigner Gina Miller, Tony Robinson and Caroline Lucas MP join with crowds Crowds gather on Pall MallA man resembling Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, joins EU supportersPeople gather in Trafalgar Square Pro-EU campaigner Gina Miller and Tony RobinsonEU supporters, calling on the government to give Britons a vote on the final Brexit deal, participate in the 'People's Vote' marchAnn&nbspPettifor, an economist who advises&nbspJohn McDonnell, the shadow chancellor, said:&nbsp“I am no fan of the EU elite. I voted ‘out’ in 1975 and I have fought the advance of neo-liberal orthodoxy for decades. But Brexit&nbspisn’t just about Britain’s membership of the EU. Its right wing proponents are the British franchise of a global movement, stretching from Trump in America to&nbspOrban&nbspin Hungary,&nbspSalvini&nbspin Italy and Marine Le Pen in France. &nbsp“Its effects will be to bolster these far-right and neo-fascist movements internationally, and domestically to further deregulate the economy and attack working class people. That’s why I’ll be backing a People’s Vote at this year’s Labour conference.”The move to have the issue&nbspdebated at Labour conference is likely to raise pressure on Mr Corbyn to soften his Brexit stance. A number of senior Labour figures, including shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer, have suggested the party could join calls for a&nbspPeople’s Vote. But the Labour leader has insisted: “It’s not our policy to have a second referendum, it’s out policy to respect the result of the referendum.”It&nbspcomes amid&nbspsigns of growing support for a fresh referendum&nbspamong left-wing supporters of Mr Corbyn. The influential Momentum campaign group&nbspis set to vote on a motion calling for a People’s Vote after a&nbsppetition started by a member in the London borough of Tower Hamlets received&nbspthe 4,000 signatures needed to trigger a ballot of all&nbspMomentum members.&nbspIf passed, it&nbspwould put Momentum&nbspat odds with Mr Corbyn, who the organisation&nbspwas founded to support.&nbspRees-Mogg suggests a second Brexit referendum would be acceptable in clip from 2011The Labour for a People’s Vote motion says the Brexit strategy&nbspbeing pursued by Theresa May “is a threat to jobs, freedom of movement, peace in Northern Ireland, and the future of the NHS and public services”.It continues: “Tory Brexit will wreck the British economy, will commit us to a series of long-term trade deals which will enforce American-style deregulation, and will undermine the rights, freedoms and protections currently enshrined in EU law. All of this will bind the hands of a future Labour government, and will make it far harder for us to deliver on our promises.”It says Labour must “oppose any Brexit deal that does not satisfy Labour’s six&nbsptests” and instead “call for an immediate general election, and make a manifesto commitment to call a public vote on the Brexit deal with an option to remain in the EU if the public rejects it”.Leading scientists back call for Brexit deal voteMore than 500,000 back The Independent’s Final Say on Brexit campaignAs a Momentum member, this is why I back a Final SayNational Union of Students backs The Independent’s Final Say campaign If the party “cannot get a general election”, the motion says it should “campaign for a public vote on the deal with an option to remain in the EU and following a defeat for the government,&nbspcall for an immediate general election”.&nbspThe launch of the campaign&nbspcoincides with&nbspa nationwide “Left Against Brexit” tour to encourage left-wing activists to speak out against Brexit. Organised by the cross-party Another Europe is Possible group, events have been held in a number of major cities and many more are planned for the coming weeks.&nbspMarina&nbspPrentoulis, a spokesperson for Another Europe is Possible, said: “Time is up on the Brexit process, and the only version of Brexit we are going to get is a Tory one. If Labour comes to power before exit day, we will be faced with a choice between no deal and an off-the-shelf Norway-style deal – a choice between economic catastrophe and a becoming a rule taker with no say in the making of EU rules. No one voted for this, and implementing it&nbspisn’t the democratic option.“Democracy means giving the people the right to determine their own future, with a referendum on the terms of the Brexit deal with an option to stay in the EU if it is rejected.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereLabour for a People's VoteEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Kianga's mother Lunar (Image: NC)She has been spotted alongside her mother Lunar parading across the reserve&rsquos 110 acres of Kentish savannah.Live coverage of Kianga&rsquos birth on the reserve&rsquos YouTube and Facebook channels attracted worldwide fascination earlier this spring, mirroring last year&rsquos amazing scenes when April went into Labour.Port Lympne&rsquos animal director Simon Jeffery described the moments when the baby giraffe made her appearance.&ldquoKianga clearly loves exploring the African Experience and although she is quite adventurous, she doesn&rsquot stray far from her mother, he said. &ldquoThe rest of the herd were keen to meet her and the boys are being very protective of her.                April the giraffe pregnant: When is April the giraffe due?                 Stop pulling my leg, you won&rsquot win this fight by a long neck&ldquoWe would like to thank all our supporters for helping us name both of our giraffe calves. We all feel that it&rsquos a very fitting name.&ldquoKianga, our female calf&rsquos name means, sunshine or sunbeam &ndash also a very apt name.Today thousands of giraffe fans have been watching April and her calf Tajiri enjoying the fine weather at her Animal Adventure Park home in upstate New York. story: The newlyweds were invited to look round Adelaide Cottage in Windsor to see if they would like to live there, according to the Mail on Sunday.Until now, the royal couple have lived together in the 1,300 square foot Nottingham Cottage in Kensington Palace.After Harry and Meghan viewed Adelaide Cottage and took a liking to it, it is understood the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are preparing to make it their second home.Adelaide Cottage is set to welcome the Duke and Duchess of Sussex  (Image: Matrixpictures*PA)Meghan, Duchess of Sussex and Prince Harry pictured at the wedding of Charlie Van Straubenzee and Daisy Jenks at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, in Surrey                    REUTERS1 of 17Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, arrives at the wedding of Charlie Van Straubenzee and Daisy JenksIt comes after reports emerged saying the Queen gave the couple York Cottage in Sandringham Estate as a wedding gift in April.Adelaide Cottage is not privately owned but is part of the Crown Estates, which means that the couple would acquire a long lease, but would not actually own the home.The grade two listed property is tucked away in the Home Park in Windsor, close to Frogmore House, which was where the international couple celebrated their wedding reception in May.                Meghan Markle captured in raspberry-fun video BEFORE she was a royal                Meghan Markle sister denies rumours Meghan will reunite with her dadThe park is private and so the Duke and Duchess would be able to enjoy their privacy without fear of intrusion by the public.The home was first built in the 1800s as retreat for King William IV&rsquos wife Queen Adelaide.The house was also used by Queen Victoria and Prince Albert as a place for them to relax away from royal life.The Queen has rumoured to have given the royal couple the generous gift  (Image: )In 1945, Group Captain Peter Townsend moved in to the house and most recently the house has been occupied by Simon Rhodes, who is the son of Margaret Rhodes, who was the first cousin of the Queen.Due to the fact the cottage is a heritage property, the couple will not be able to redecorate or renovate as renters.The pair were last seen out in public on Saturday at the wedding of Harry's childhood friend Charlie van Straubenzee to filmmaker Daisy Jenks in Surrey.The cottage is set in the grounds of Windsor Castle  (Image: Getty)The event was on the same day as Meghan's 37th birthday and Prince Harry was a best man.Their attendance follows a trying time for Meghan, after her father Thomas Markle gave an explosive interview to the Mail on Sunday.The former Hollywood lighting director claimed the Royal Family had forced Meghan to freeze him out as he dragged Harry&rsquos later mother Princess Diana into the row.

title: Brexit news David Davis Liam Fox Theresa May Michel Barnier leave EU Brussels Macron
story: Senior Whitehall sources said on Saturday night if the UK crashes out of the EU without a deal &ldquowe will make clear whose fault it was.They point to Article 8 of the treaty, which states the EU must develop a special relationship with neighbouring countries, aiming to establish an area of prosperity and good neighbourliness, founded on the values of the Union and characterised by close and peaceful relations based on cooperation.A senior Whitehall source said: &ldquoWe have made an offer that some people think is on the generous side and the EU has to know we are not kidding.&ldquoIf they don&rsquot like our offer they need to come back and say what the alternative is, but they can&rsquot just keep stalling.                Farage issues BLISTERING rant amid fears of 'backroom Barnier deal'                Brexit News: Farage predicts UK-EU campaign to SUSPEND Article 50&ldquoThey also need to accept that we&rsquove done nothing wrong. We left under the terms of the Lisbon Treaty, which says they have obligations to help us.&ldquoThe way they are behaving is making things difficult and if we end up with no deal we will make it clear whose fault it was.Meanwhile, speaking to The Daily  the former Brexit secretary David Davis cautioned Brussels would be making a &ldquomassive miscalculation if it thought the UK was not ready to walk away without a deal.He said: &ldquoThe Lisbon Treaty requires them to come up with a workable arrangement and that&rsquos certainly not the description of their behaviour at the moment.Mr Davis has warned Brussels it would be making a massive miscalculation if it underestimated the UK (Image:  )Theresa May laughed with Angela Merkel after meeting the German chancellor only hours after Brexit chaos resignations                    REUTERS1 of 15Theresa May has met Angela Merkel only hours after the Cabinet's Brexit turmoilHe added: &ldquoThis has great scope for being a massive miscalculation on the part of the EU that could end up with no deal by accident.Mr Davis said it was not the intention of the EU to have a no deal Brexit but they were misjudging the UK at the moment.He argued the UK Parliament did not want a no deal scenario but it was certainly not going to be pushed around by the European Parliament.But the former Brexit Minister conceded he had always believed no deal would be better than a bad deal and, while there would be border issues, it would give the UK more freedom.He said: &ldquoI&rsquom still of the view that we have got two things on our side - we have got our own currency and we are masters of our own destiny in a way that EU member countries are not.&ldquoThis is a negotiation and it will go to the edge, but we must not panic about this.&ldquoThey have got lots to lose too, and specific countries and specific sectors have got large amounts to lose. As we get closer to the brink there will be internal pressure within the EU.Mr Davis&rsquos comments came after the International Trade Secretary Dr Liam Fox warned the UK was set to crash out the EU with no deal in an extraordinary interview with The Sunday Times.Dr Fox put the chances of deal at &ldquo60-40 and blamed the prospect of no deal on the &ldquointransigence of the Brussels machine.His pessimistic outlook comes despite both sides claiming they intend to reach an agreement on Brexit terms by March 2019.The International Trade Secretary has blamed the EU's intransigence for the prospect of no deal  (Image:  )Mrs May attempted to win the French President over during a recent visit to his Riviera retreat  (Image:  )He told the Sunday Times: I think the intransigence of the commission is pushing us towards no deal.We have set out the basis in which a deal can happen but if the EU decides that the theological obsession of the unelected is to take priority over the economic wellbeing of the people of Europe then it's a bureaucrats' Brexit - not a people's Brexit - then there is only going to be one outcome.The International Trade Secretary, whose job it is to galvanise trade with the rest of the world, argued Mr Barnier had dismissed the UK&rsquos Chequers proposals thrashed out by Theresa May simply because &ldquowe have never done it before.The Government has conceded its proposals are unprecedented, but Dr Fox said Mr Barnier&rsquos response &ldquomakes the chance of no deal greater.Downing Street insisted Theresa May was still &ldquoconfident of getting a good deal, despite Dr Fox&rsquos comments.Number 10 also remained tight-lipped about Mrs May&rsquos visit to French President Emmanuel Macron on Friday, during which they discussed Brexit.EU diplomats have said neither Mr Macron nor the German Chancellor Angela Merkel had budged their position since the Chequers proposals were thrashed out by the cabinet last month.

story: John Bruton, the former Irish prime minister, told LBC&rsquos Tom Swarbrick that the UK had conducted Brexit &rsquoback to front&rsquo which had caused delays in negotiations.Mr Bruton said: The problem here is that Britain has done it back to front.It wrote a letter saying it wanted to leave the EU - the Article 50 letter - and then only started to make up its mind as to what particular type of arrangement it wanted to have with the European Union.Mr Swarbrick pointed out that the EU had stated that there could be no negotiations until Article 50 had been triggered.Brexit has been conducted 'back to front,' according to John Bruton.   (Image: LBC&bullBBC)Mr Bruton replied: &ldquoThat&rsquos true as far as the negotiating with the EU is concerned. The Conservative Party had to negotiate with itself first to decide what sort of Brexit it wanted.&ldquoEventually, well into the short time limit that existed, about three weeks ago with its own proposal and some in the government seem to expect that once the government has come up with its proposal, that all the other 27 countries simply have to say yes to what Britain wants.&ldquoWell, unfortunately with a union of 27 different countries it isn&rsquot that easy to do that. Particularly when your a rule-bound and treaty bound organisation, where changing the treaties, for example, requires unanimity.&nbspA trade agreement that Britain might make with the European Union would have the agreed in the parliaments of all member states.The former Irish leader said the impact of Brexit on his country was being disregarded.He said: &ldquoRemember, Brexit is a British decision. We had no say in this decision, and it's a decision that has huge implications for us.Northern Ireland voted to remain in the European Union, that's being disregarded. Scotland voted to remain in the European Union, and that's being disregarded - because England wants to leave.Mr Bruton agreed with International Trade Secretary Dr Liam Fox that the chances of no deal were 60-40. title: canterbury traveller site gypsy dunkirk parish swale borough council
story: The Brotherhood Wood travellers site at Dunkirk (Image: SWNS)Nearly 100 caravans will now be permitted in the tiny village of Dunkirk outside Canterbury despite allegations the site is already overcrowded - meaning travellers are likely to outnumber residents.Swale Borough Council approved an application to increase the number of pitches at the Brotherhood Wood site from 29 to 40, which means the number of caravans will more than double from 42 to 87.Dunkirk Parish Council is appealing the controversial decision, which it described as seriously perverse.The owners of the site had their application denied by councillors in March but a planning committee narrowly granted permission in April.                Fury as travellers ruin Lord of the Rings beauty spot leaving rubbish                RUBBISH! Travellers FURIOUS over litter on illegal camp siteIt went ahead despite allegations that Brotherhood Wood already has too many residents, and amid investigations into claims that many are not travellers or gypsies, but migrant workers from Eastern Europe who are not permitted to live there.In an open letter to Swale's cabinet member for planning, Councillor Gerry Lewin, the parish council's chairman Jeff Tutt is now asking Swale to reconsider, saying it has the power to revoke permission under the Town and Country Planning Act.Calling the decision to allow the site to grow seriously perverse, the letter stated the borough council completely ignored the many and varied material considerations that were put forward for refusal.Concerns were also raised that, under the new layout, some families could have a space smaller than the minimum size of a one-bedroom flat to live in, and that Kent Police usually recommend that traveller sites have no more than 15 pitches.It is also feared that a larger number of pitches at the site could be used as grounds to refuse permission for gypsies and travellers to reside in other places.The number of pitches at the Brotherhood Wood site set to increase from 29 to 40 (Image: SWNS)A spokesman for Swale Borough Council said that although potential planning breaches are still being investigated, the authority is not considering revoking permission.It has argued that refusing an application without sound planning reasons could leave it open to an expensive appeal process.Replying to the letter, director of regeneration Emma Wiggins said: I cannot agree with your position that it was unreasonable for the experienced and well advised Planning Committee to determine the application in the way that it was advised to do.Considering the application on its merits, it was resolved to permit the application. This decision was made by the committee, who were fully alive to the local opposition.There would seem to be no merit in seeking to revoke the permission granted by the committee in such circumstances in the absence of any new material considerations having come to light.

title: Elgin womans nightmare journey to give birth
story: Margaret Ross suffered a 66-mile journey in labour in an ambulance that ran out of painkillers (Image: NC)Margaret Ross, from Elgin, gave birth to her fifth child, Arrabella, less than a week after Dr Gray&rsquos Hospital in the Morayshire town was downgraded because of a staffing crisis.During the journey to Aberdeen she was told to &ldquostop pushing amid fears her baby would have to be delivered en route.And she was forced to endure the final stages of the journey without painkillers after supplies ran out.Mrs Ross, 39, was originally due to give birth at Dr Gray&rsquos Hospital but then it was downgraded. An appointment was made for her to be induced at Aberdeen Maternity Hospital, only for Mrs Ross to then be rushed there in an ambulance after she went into labour two days early.Now NHS Grampian are to contact her directly to discuss her experience.Mrs Ross said: &ldquoIt was horrific. Absolutely horrendous. Just as we were coming into Aberdeen the midwives asked me to stop pushing.&ldquoI was strapped in the entire time. During labour you have to move around and I just couldn&rsquot. I&rsquove still got bruises on my legs. I&rsquove had four pregnancies. I&rsquove had to be transferred to Dundee with premature twins and had a baby moved with forceps but this was the worst childbirth I&rsquove had.&ldquoIt was a heartbreaking thing to go through.&ldquoI don&rsquot think Aberdeen can cope either. The midwife had to leave another woman in labour to see me when I came through the door and then I was left for two hours after giving birth.&ldquoI don&rsquot know how a first-time mum would have coped with being left like that.                Father delivers premature baby at home with help of HEADPHONESShe added: &ldquoOur last baby was born in Elgin and it was perfect.&ldquoThe NHS should be ashamed having to make mothers go through this.Husband Charlie drove behind the ambulance all the way along the A96 with no way of knowing how she was doing.Arrabella was delivered in Aberdeen in the early hours of July 25. She is now doing well at the family home in Elgin, surrounded by big brothers Cameron, Laughlan and Louis and sister Alexis.Health campaigner Kirsty Watson, a member of the Keep Mum campaign group, said: &ldquoThis is just one example of what might happen by making families make this journey. It&rsquos why we are campaigning to have our unit reinstated as soon as possible.NHS Grampian insisted a staff shortage at Dr Gray&rsquos means transfers to Aberdeen or Inverness will remain the safest option for medium and high-risk pregnancies.The health board has now been given two weeks to submit plans to reintroduce a consultant-led maternity service at Dr Gray&rsquos Hospital.Health Secretary Jeane Freeman imposed the strict deadline as she visited the Elgin hospital to hear concerns from staff and locals about the downgrade.The maternity service was changed from consultant-led to midwife-led last month, meaning that medium and high-risk births will have to take place elsewhere.Now Ms Freeman has told the health board to come up with a plan and deliver it to her &ldquotwo weeks from today.

title: uk weather forecast met office long range forecast autumn weather
story: For many autumn signifies brown leaves and cooler weather (Image: MET OFFICE )The beginning of this week has been another warm one, with temperatures reaching over 30C in the south of England.&nbspIn Essex and Norfolk, temperatures could reach 34C on Tuesday following the hot weekend where the mercury reached 30C.&nbspThe north, Scotland and Northern Ireland have seen weather resume to somewhat normal - as cooler air sweeps in accompanied by rain.&nbspThe south will see cooler weather too towards the end of this week, with the potential for heavy rain and thunderstorms to clear the air.&nbsp                Sleep - trick you can do with a household item to help you fall asleep                Japan weather MAPPED: Where could Typhoon Shanshan make landfall?When will cooler autumn weather hit the UK?&nbspAutumn for many signals a time when leaves begin to turn brown, and a cool snap is in the air.&nbspNights have already begun to get shorter, and mornings darker as we get closer to the cooler months.&nbspHowever, there are two dates for autumn beginning - for meteorologists, summer will end on Friday, August 31 and autumn begin on Saturday, September 1.But astronomers say summer ends on September 22 with the Autumnal Equinox in the northern hemisphere and autumn begins on Sunday, September 23.The Autumnal equinox signifies the astronomical start of autumn in the Northern Hemisphere and spring in the Southern Hemisphere.The end of autumn officially falls on Friday, December 21 when winter begins.&nbspHow hot will autumn be?With the extended period of heat the UK has experienced in recent weeks, many will be welcoming colder temperatures with open arms.Temperatures are set to reach over 30 degrees in the coming days  (Image: MET OFFICE)Luckily for those sick of the hot weather, the Met Office&rsquos three-month outlook suggests that the hot weather will die down soon.&nbspHowever, the UK may experience a &ldquowarmer than average autumn according to Met Office spokeswoman, Bonnie Diamond.The prediction for the next three months shows that there is an increased chance of high-pressure weather systems coming close to the UK, causing more settled conditions.&nbspThis is a change from the unsettled weather from our typical Atlantic weather systems.Autumn could see hotter temperatures than usual due to changing weather systems (Image: )Ms Diamond said: This means there is an increased likelihood of warmer-than-average temperatures and below-average rainfall.It must be noted, however, that this does not necessarily mean temperatures will be hot or that a 'heatwave will continue', as above-average temperatures can mean one or two degrees above average, for which August, September and October are 19, 16 and 13 Celsius respectively.Further, warmer-than-average temperatures does not necessarily mean sunshine - it can be warm and cloudy too.

title: dog meat soup south korea asia bosintang
story: Bosintang literally translates as &ldquoinvigorating soup and is a spicy stew made with dog which Koreans believe has medicinal properties.It is believed to increase virility and is still quite popular.While dog is not listed as a livestock, it is not illegal to prepare the meal in restaurants.The dogs bred for consumption have a different name from dogs bred as pets and pet dogs are never eaten.Dogs bred for meat are called Nureongi.                Rabies WARNING: Diseased animal found in Far East dog and cat meat                 Inside the sick market where 80,000 dogs are SLAUGHTERED for food Bosintang is eaten on the three hottest days of the year to keep strength up.Dog meat is the fourth most popular meat in South Korea, after beef, chicken and pork.The soup is prepared by boiling the dog meat with various vegetables like onions and perlla leaves.It has a taste and texture close to goat.It is the most popular dish containing dog meat in South Korea, but it is not the only one.It is believed to increase virility and is still quite popular (Image: )While dog is not listed as a livestock, it is not illegal to prepare the meal in restaurants (Image: )Diners can also have dog meat steamed with vegetables and spices, or even a medical tonic called &ldquogaesoju which is made from dog, ginger, chestnut and jujube.But there has been pressure on the South Korean government to make the dog meat trade illegal.Less than a third of Koreans have tried dog meat and even fewer eat it regularly.Animal rights campaigner from Passion For Compassion said there is a generational ide in Korea.Dog meat is consumed more often by adults with younger generations shunning the dish.For westerners, the idea of eating dog tends to be frowned upon (Image: )She said: &ldquoIt is a generational thing and people are beginning to fight against it.&ldquoI have hope for South Korea banning the dog meat trade.For westerners, the idea of eating dog tends to be frowned upon.During the Winter Olympics in Seoul, CNN called the trade &ldquobrutal and sinister while The Mirror wrote about the &ldquohell of dog farms.A commenter on the website eatinkorea said they could not mentally get past the idea of eating dogs.                    AFPGetty Images1 of 18Puppies are seen in a cage at a dog meat market in Yulin, in China's southern Guangxi regionSaying: &ldquoI couldn't mentally get around eating dog...plus the smell is very different and not at all appetising to me.&ldquoI&rsquom sorry I went to try this, and I'm glad it's losing popularity in many cities, especially among younger generations.But not every review is critical as according to a report from Vice, the soup is &ldquoshamefully nice.The report said: &ldquoI'm eating dog out of sheer curiosity, but I have to admit that it doesn't taste as bad as I imagined.&ldquoThe meat has been cooked with chamomile and dandelion and a lot of Korean spices. The soup comes with a sauce called deul-gge, made of perilla seeds, sesame oil and red chilli paste.&ldquoIt seems to bring out more flavour, but I also have the sneaking suspicion that it's served to lessen the overpowering smell of the meat.

title: EU news germany trade surplus Michael Ivanovitch Angela Merkel
story: Last year, Angela Merkel&rsquos country had more than a 159 billion euro surplus on its goods trade with other countries in the EU.This year the surplus has broken another record as the surplus during the January-April period was running at an annual rate of 175 billion euros, according to the Bundesbank in Germany.This is a 10 percent increase on the county&rsquos EU trades in 2017.This week, the chief economist at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) Maurice Obstfeld said that Germany&rsquos hesitancy to reduce its trade surplus was contributing to trade tensions.Germany has been accused of stifling the bloc with its huge trade surplus  (Image: )Merkel delivered a government declaration to the members of the German parliament Bundestag prior a meeting of the European Council on 28 and 29 June and the NATO summit on 11 and 12 July 2018. story: The MP for North East Somerset caused controversy after airing his views on abortion and gay marriage. Then, on August 2018 his Somerset home was vandalised. Heres his story...Jacob Rees-Mogg is a backbench Tory MP for North East Somerset but is better known for his period drama persona which has been winning him fans.He entered parliament during the 2010 General Election after working as a fund manager in London.During the EU referendum, he was a passionate Brexiteer and made many high-profile media appearances arguing for a vote to leave the EU.To say he was born into a privileged position is an understatement - he is the Eton and Oxford-educated son of the long-serving Times editor William Rees-Mogg.During the 1997 General Election Rees-Mogg attracted ridicule.This is because he brought his faithful nanny along with him as he battled to be elected in the working class and staunchly Labour seat of Central Fife.He has batted away speculation that he would challenge Theresa May for the leadership of the party, insisting he was completely loyal to her.Mogg said he was more likely to become POPE than PM.Outside the political arena, Jacob is a family man with six children.His wife is journalist Helena de Chair, daughter of the aristocrat Somerset de Chair.He celebrated the birth of his sixth child with a touching picture on Instagram.He wrote: Helena and I announce with great joy that we have a baby Sixtus Dominic Boniface Christopher, a brother for Peter, Mary, Thomas, Anselm and Alfred.In May 2018 it was reported by The Mail on Sunday that he had purchased a new £5million house just around the corner from No 10 Downing Street.The five-storey mansion is just a short walk away from the Parliament and is also close to Tory HQ in the heart of Old Westminster.Rees-Mogg joked he had been priced out of swanky Mayfair and needed a bigger home for his six children.The children’s comic has accused the Tory of copying its character Walter the Softy - by wearing round glasses, liking classical music and being snooty.The publication says it has sent the politician a letter  for him to cease and desist from “impersonating” Dennis the Menace’s antagonist, saying he was around first.Beanos Mike Stirling accused Rees-Mogg of masquerading as Walter Brown, after the similarities were spotted by young readers of the comic and its beano website.He said: We were flattered when we discovered that Jacob Rees-Mogg has dedicated his life to impersonating one of my favourite Beano characters, young Walter.Nonetheless, as a hard-working British media company, we would prefer the public gets its Walter fix in the pages of our comics and on Beano , rather than played out on the political stage. In other words, bog off Rees-Mogg!But Rees-Mogg said: “Compared to me Walter is a tough guy.”In February Rees-Mogg attended a talk at the University of West England (UWE) in Bristol.However, the night was marred after a group of protesters wearing balaclavas burst into the room, with witnesses saying they were chanting fascist scum in the MPs direction.Video from the scuffle appears to show the Brexiteer attempting to stop a clash between protesters and onlookers.Bristol University student William Brown told The Sun Online he first noticed the fire doors rattling, with the group of protesters bursting into the room.He said: These people in balaclavas and sunglasses started shouting, things like Tory fascist.They were quite intimidating actually.They were waving their hands around, shouting very loudly. He said that a few punches were thrown, but no one appeared to be badly injured.Due to his strict Catholic beliefs, Mogg admitted on ITVs Good Morning Britain that he did not support abortion even in the case of rape and incest.I am completely opposed to abortion, life begins at conception, he said.Abortion is morally indefensible.The MP has also repeatedly voted against sex marriage legislation.He defended everyones right to free speech, and insisted that if he ever became Prime Minister, the law is not going to change.Soon after Rees-Mogg made his remarks it emerged the millionaire MP was making money out of an abortion pill despite his strong stance against it.Somerset Capital Management, the investment company he co-founded, owns nearly £5million of shares in Indonesian firm Kalbe Farma.Reacting to the story, Rees Mogg told The Mirror: This is not something I would wish to invest in personally but you have a duty as an investment manager not to impose constraints on investors.Mr Rees-Mogg added: This company does not procure the abortion of babies.It’s not my money in these investments and I profit from the total amount of client money we hold, not the investments we make.The Made in Chelsea star and this years Im A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here winner has admitted she has the hots for Rees-Mogg.In an interview with the Sunday Times, Georgia Toff Toffolo revealed the politicians she admired “the standard - Zac Goldsmith, Jacob Rees-Mogg. I fancy them all, adding: Jacob’s a sex god.”The reality star said elaborated: “The human mind can be sexy. He’s so clever, I just love him, adding: “I fancy middle-aged politicians, but I’ve never been with one.”Rees-Mogg has responded to news of the 23-year-olds crush, saying he was “greatly surprised but nonetheless flattered” by the revelation.“I am glad Miss Toffolo won and hope this is the launchpad for a glittering career,” he added.It happened on August 1, 2018 when the Rees-Mogg family were on holiday in the US.According to the police graffiti was sprayed on a building and on a car as well as the garden.They managed to write posh scum on windows of the house.The MPs 17th Century country home, called Gournay Court, is a listed building.He also owns a £5.6m house in Westminster.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: india wine alcohol laws legal age drinking public
story: The rules can vary widely from alcohol consumption being prohibited to even the legal age you are allowed to drink varies widely.You can.But in the states of Bihar, Gujarat and Nagaland there is a ban on alcohol as well as some parts of Manipur.In Goa it is 18.In Maharashtra it has different ages for different drinks. title: karren brady switch off phone
story: Remember the days when a mobile phone was like a hulking great brick? Available only to the elite few who could afford them at first, they were designed purely to enable people to take a call while away from home.Fast forward a couple of decades and we are all glued to our devices, a nation of addicts.We are now so wedded to our smartphones that we check them every 12 minutes.The average Brit spends more than a day a week online, twice as long as ten years ago.This surge in time online is largely down to the rise of smartphones, which are now used by 78 per cent of the population compared with just 17 per cent in 2008.My personal bugbear is people who walk along the street in a slow zig-zag because they are glued to their phone.And there’s nothing worse than someone who interrupts a conversation to take a call or read a text.It surely can’t be a coincidence that, in the same week as this report was released, we hear about five-year-olds starting school unable to speak in sentences — partly, no doubt, down to parents plugging them into a screen rather than talking or reading to them.I’ve got a Blackberry, mainly because I like the keyboard. But I am probably as hooked on it as the next person.It’s an invaluable tool for anyone wanting to work flexibly. But I also do a fair amount of pointless surfing on it.I’m not into all forms of social media, but I am a bit of a news junkie and I’ll confess I also watch the odd funny YouTube film with my kids.Unfortunately, progress in technology has brought the idea that we “should” all be available 24/7.In fact, people are quite indignant if you don’t reply to an email within the hour — even if it’s sent at 4am.Being a conscientious type, the result for me if I’m not careful, is that if I wake up in the night I’ll check my emails and maybe even reply to a few before going back to sleep. Now that can’t be good for the old circadian rhythms.The other problem with everyone being always available and always “on” is that our FOMO — fear of missing out — has increased exponentially.We’re all terrified that if we’re offline for too long we won’t get to . . . what exactly? See photos of someone’s hashtag perfect holibobs with the famalam — and then feel like our life is rubbish by comparison?I use Twitter a bit but I avoid Facebook and Instagram, partly because I don’t want the possibility that the opinions and “likes” of people I don’t know may influence me more than my own values and views.And another problem with the prevalence of tech is that we don’t have any down time.All those previously blank moments — on the bus, waiting for our microwave meal to cook, lying in bed at night — have all become an opportunity to surf, tweet, and message. We are going to burn out if we aren’t careful.I always know when I’m really relaxed because I accidentally go out without my phone.Granted, it generally only happens when I’m on holiday.But now I know how close we are to becoming actual addicts, I feel like we should all build in some time away from our devices.After all, the more time we spend looking at a screen, the less time we spend looking at the world and engaging with other people.So maybe we should all take a moment to leave our phone at home, go for a walk, and switch from “on” to “off”.Isn’t that a liberating thought?I’M sure a fair few people felt a bit guilty reading about the Vogue interview with Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie this week.The sisters talk about how hard it is living in the public eye but also the criticism and mockery they face, often attacked for taking too many holidays.Who knows, perhaps some of that criticism is justified.But a lot of the comments they get are about their appearance and clothes – and that is where it crosses a line.No-one chooses the family into which they are born, and they are trying to make the best of the hand they’ve been given.They are trying to build careers and have a personal life while being in the public eye and that can’t be easy.I hope people realise that and give them a break.HAVING spent the past couple of decades getting annoyed at anyone who utters the words “Poor Jennifer Aniston”, this week, for the first time ever, I said them myself.You know why?Because the 49-year-old has been forced to publicly address, again, the tedious topic of why she hasn’t had a baby.She also alluded to something no woman should have to share with anyone they don’t want to, let alone the world – the fact she might be medically unable to procreate.Poor Jen. She can’t just get on with her very successful – and no doubt happy – life without being plagued by speculation.In the same interview she took the chance to spell it out: Just because she split from Justin Theroux doesn’t mean her life is over.She might even be happy to have finally got shot of him.“The misconceptions are ‘Jen can’t keep a man’,” she said. “And ‘Jen refuses to have a baby because she’s selfish and committed to her career.’ Or that I’m sad and heartbroken . . . first, with all due respect, I’m not heartbroken. And second, those are reckless assumptions.“No one knows what’s going on behind closed doors. No one considers how sensitive that might be for my partner and me. They don’t know what I’ve been through medically or emotionally.“There is a pressure on women to be mothers, and if they are not, then they’re deemed damaged goods. Maybe my purpose on this planet isn’t to procreate. Maybe I have other things I’m supposed to do.”So yes. Poor, poor Jen being under the world’s watchful and pitying eye all the time.Just to remind people. Jennifer Aniston is one of the world’s most successful stars.She has a big group of friends and a beautiful home, which she bought herself. She has dogs she adores, she’s funny, busy, and fulfilled.But all of that is worth nothing, of course. She doesn’t have kids.To anyone reading this who thinks women must have children to be fulfilled, please take note: Plenty of women don’t want to get married or have kids.Many other women want kids but can’t have them.And guess what? It’s none of our business.Here’s another way of looking at Jennifer’s life. She is lucky.She gets to please herself and hasn’t had to make any of the sacrifices that many of us make to become mothers.Also, George Clooney didn’t meet Amal until he was 51. Hugh Grant got married this year at 57 (after many failed relationships). Leonardo DiCaprio, 43, and Jude Law, 45, are still single and dating. Has anyone ever said: “Poor George/Hugh/Leonardo/Jude”?Of course they haven’t. So let’s stop saying it about Jennifer, too.I SO related to Carol Vorderman’s delight at being asked for proof of age when she bought some wine at M&ampS recently.When you’re young, being asked to prove your age, as the presenter, above, was is very annoying. But as time goes by it’s one of life’s little victories.Having said that, this hasn’t happened to me in Aldi. Maybe I ought to go to M&ampS!I’M truly appalled by the news that the Home Office “turns a blind eye” to the plight of British teenagers who are being forced to marry abroad, then raped and impregnated – after which the ministerial department actually hands a visa to their husbands.These young British women in question are forced abroad, or told they are going on holiday, but in reality are forced into a marriage and to get pregnant so that they can apply for a UK visa for their “husband”.Officials received dozens of reports last year that women wanted to block visas for men they had been made to marry in countries including Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and the United Arab Emirates.But in almost half of their cases the visas were approved nonetheless! And experts believe that there are thousands more victims who are too afraid to come forward.The women forced into this situation must be absolutely terrified, not least because their own family is complicit in this abuse.The authorities when granting the visa do not actually speak to the “wife”. There is no whistle-blowing process or opportunity for the women to make a confidential statement. Any statement made is public.Authorities fear that if they block the visa they will be called racists, but this is a safeguarding issue and that fear of causing offence really has to stop.We need to get on top of the problem by working with schools to raise awareness, so girls know how to report it.And we need to work with social workers so they can recognise the family members are the perpetrators of this crime.GOSH, how shocking is the video footage of a woman called Arabella Juniper Torres calling the police to report a woman, who happened to be black, for sheltering in her doorway in Brooklyn, New York, while waiting for her Uber?We are living in the age of the death of the Good Samaritan.I helped someone carry a pushchair downstairs at the Tube last week – as all the burly men walked past, I might add.She was so grateful it made me realise small acts of kindness have all but disappeared. How about this for an idea: let’s all try to be kind.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what happened to british male
story: I grew up in a typical working-class neighbourhood where all forms of violence against women were strictly taboo.Somewhere between my youth and today, that old taboo has vanished.I look at what we have become, a nation where violence against women is shockingly common, and I do not recognise it as the land I grew up in.In a sunny park, a pack of leering teenage boys pose proudly around a cowering middle-aged woman who they have ritually abused, pelting her with flour, water and eggs until she is bent into submission.At chucking-out time at an Essex nightclub, a young man punches a young woman in the face until she lies senseless on the pavement.What the hell has happened to the young British male?How did he ever become such a vicious, bullying, woman-hating coward?I saw violence and bullying when I was growing up in my little corner of Essex, but I never saw anything even remotely like these despicably ugly scenes.What kind of homes did these creeps grow up in?What do they imagine it takes to be a man? And how did they get so sick that they believe their behaviour is socially acceptable?These women-hating bullies — Liam Holmes, 20, who battered a woman to the ground outside Faces nightclub, and the five smirking thugs who tormented a vulnerable woman but can’t be named because they are under 18 — are not the products of brutal, inner-city gangland.These blights on the face of British manhood are the product of ordinary homes, God help us.They are what our young men look like now.They are not feral kids who never had a chance.They are not the products of deprived lives.The leering bullies posing proudly around their terrified victim in that sun-drenched park are growing up in Bury St Edmunds, a peaceful Suffolk market town with pretty cottages and a lovely cathedral, while Liam Holmes attacked his victim outside a club that was once a fashionable oasis for footballers and pop stars, the Essex answer to New York’s Studio 54.These thugs all have dear old mums who love them to bits.Indeed, the mother of one of the park scum sacks — a woman who must have an IQ lower than her dress size — complained that her son was the one suffering now because the backlash has ruined his 16th birthday.The poor little lamb! What’s the world coming to if you and your mates can’t torture a vulnerable middle-aged woman in the park any more?Personally, I hope the backlash ruins his life.And while we ponder these pitiful excuses for young men, let us spare a thought for their female victims.The 18-year-old woman who was punched to the ground by Liam Holmes has been predictably abused in the sewer of social media, informed “she deserved it” for daring to speak back to a man, and gloatingly told that, “she had a lesson in true equality.Meanwhile the vulnerable 49-year-old woman who was brutalised in the park has spoken with incredible restraint about her experience, which must have been as humiliating as it was frightening.“Considering the respective ages of all parties and that it was five or six young men versus me alone, I remain surprised that they behaved in such a way towards me,” she said.“I would like to hear their reasons, if possible.”Which is so mild-mannered that I find it breaks my bloody heart.It is tempting to blame the surge in violence against women on social media, and brainless morons like the little d**ks in that park taking pictures to show off to their mates. But it can’t all be blamed on social media.I bet Liam Holmes wishes there were no cameras around when he was smashing a woman in the jaw.“He wouldn’t do that for no reason,” protests his mother Cathy, 53. “There was a lot that went on before that people don’t know about.”Sorry, there can never be an excuse, reason or justification for a man or boy to abuse a woman or girl. Not ever.The old taboo about men being violent towards women should still stand.Lads, it doesn’t matter if they say something cutting to you at chucking out time.Lads, it doesn’t matter if they have the insolent cheek to sit on the park bench where you like to hang out with your bad-ass homies in the Bury St Edmunds massive.How hard is it to understand?Men should not be violent towards women.My father, the hardest man I ever met, taught me a real man does not raise his voice to a woman, let alone his hand.But that generation of tough, gentle men has gone and in their place we have pitiful excuses for the male of the species who feel empowered by belittling, beating and abusing women.And what sickens the stomach about the boys in the park is that they all look so very pleased with themselves, as if tormenting a vulnerable woman who, in the words of her stepmother “wouldn’t say boo to a goose” is the high point of their miserable lives.It is a good job their mothers all love them because I can’t imagine any other self-respecting woman ever will.“He’s never had a girlfriend,” someone remarked of woman-bashing lout, Liam Holmes.Yes, it shows. The big close-up Nicole posted on Instagram is absolutely terrifying. What a scary face! The spider, I mean. Not Nicole.HOW sweet life was for Jeremy Corbyn when he was a loopy left-wing backbencher, free to flutter his eyelashes at the IRA, to stand on platforms that compared Israel to Nazi Germany and to bowl up on Iranian TV praising the release of Hamas terrorists who had murdered Jewish children.But now fate has Corbyn as a possible Prime Minister his support of extremism is not such a good look.And no matter how pathetic this Tory Government becomes, no matter how timid, weak and gutless Theresa May looks in the face of Brussels’ bullying, the British people will never choose for Prime Minister a man who considers the child killers in Hamas to be his “brothers”.“In the past, in the pursuit of peace and justice for the Palestinian people, I have on occasion appeared on platforms with people whose views I completely reject,” apologises panicky Corbyn, a man who can feel the keys to 10 Downing Street slipping through his fingers.The past is coming back to haunt Jeremy Corbyn.And it will destroy him.It might also have something to do with the celeb fear of looking like a sweaty idiot with two left feet, while wearing nipple-crushing Lycra on prime-time television.Luckily, Nadiya Bychkova, above, will be there for her second series, the only pro dancer who looks more like a celebrity than any of the celebrities.THOSE who want the UK to remain in the European Union have never made any attempt to persuade the 17.4million who voted to leave to change our minds.They just insult us.Peter Mandelson says Brexiteers “hate other countries and hate foreigners” while Stewart Lee, a pot-bellied Bernard Manning for snowflakes, says: “It wasn’t just racists that voted to leave Europe – c**** did as well. Stupid f****** c****.”Just insults.Which is why Remain lost the referendum. And why they would lose 100 referendums.BAKE Off winner Nadiya Hussain tells Loose Women: “I work in an industry that is heavily dominated by male, middle-class, middle-aged men and there’s no space for a 5ft brown girl, who wears a headscarf.”But you became a national treasure, Nadiya.So self-pity is misplaced.MADONNA turns 60 years old on August 16 and has marked the birthday by laying provocatively on the ground sporting suspenders, lacy bra and a been-to-bed expression in her half-closed eyes.The Material Girl still looks great, of course.Mind you, she does look as though she might need a hand getting back on her feet. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn not fit pm
story: That’s the only conclusion to draw from the cack-handed way he has dealt with the vicious anti-Semitism which seems to infect every corner of his Labour Party.His first response to the latest scandal was to stick his fingers in his ears and hum the Red Flag rather than address it head-on.Even when he was forced to break his silence, he could barely bother to do anything other than copy and paste from the last time he was compelled to apologise.It is shocking, but not particularly surprising.After all this is a man who has surrounded himself with anti-Semites for decades, and has been happy to trot out dangerous conspiracy theories himself.Why would he care that Jews within his own party feel unwelcome?Why would he care that Jewish leaders see him and his party as an ‘existential threat’ to their lives here?Labour MP Joan Ryan is calling for a proper investigation into Corbyn’s comments. Fine. But this leopard is not about to change his spots.Throughout his life he has shown terrible judgment. It is extraordinary how often he picks the wrong side.He is not just a threat to British Jews if he gets into power.He’s a threat to Britain, full stop.BRUSSELS bureaucrats always put their precious project ahead of common sense.It explains their approach to Brexit negotiations.Yet our analysis of what a ‘no deal’ Brexit would mean for French pharmaceutical companies, German car manufacturers and everything in between should focus minds.You can’t just find £500 billion down the back of the sofa, Jean-Claude.The Brexit Department has its own detailed study too, but are keeping it private. title: lombok earthquake indonesia holidaymakers evacuation boats
story: Shocking footage showed a mad scramble to board tiny boats off Gili Trawangan in the wake of the magnitude-7 quake which killed 142 and injured more than 200 across Bali and Lombok.Celebs including Take That star Gary Barlow and model Chrissy Teigen were among the thousands of tourists caught up in horror scenes on the idyllic Indonesian islands.British teacher James Kelsall, 28, described scenes of utter chaos on nearby Gili Trawangan where Navy officers allegedly kicked locals to stop them climbing on boats.Kelsall, from Woodford Green in London, said more than holidaymakers were stranded on the palm-fringed island off the coast of Lombok for more than six hours today.Speaking from a beach as he awaited evacuation, he said: There was rumbling and then all the power went off. We ran to the beach to be clear of buildings which we could hear falling all around.What we know so far...Local authorities said those stranded on the Gilis - the three tropical islands popular with backpackers and divers - were being evacuated today.But footage posted online showed panicked tourists and locals packed onto powder-white beaches before climbing over each other to board tiny boats leaving the island.Meanwhile frightened residents across all affected islands, particularly north Lombok, poured out of their homes and moved to higher ground after the quake triggered a Tsunami warning.Kelsall added: It was literally the most terrifying thing I have experienced and the uncertainty of the tsunami - I had pictures of Thailand in my head from when it happened there.Pop superstar Gary Barlow was one of the unfortunate tourists whose holidays were cut abruptly short by the devastating earthquake.He shared footage of himself doing yoga in an iddylic island location in the days before the quake hit and killed more than 100 people.As and many other foreign tourists fled the country, he wrote on Twitter: I bumped into so many British families leaving Bali. How lucky we are to have that choice.I’ve had the misfortune of being in 7 earthquakes but none have felt more deep and raw as last nights.Followed by numerous after shocks. Praying for everyone affected.Michelle Thompson, an American who was holidaying on one of the Gilis with her husband, described a violent scramble to get on boats leaving for the main island.She said: People were just throwing their suitcases on board and I had to struggle to get my husband on because he was bleeding.Muhammad Faozal, head of West Nusa Tenggaras tourism agency, said: We cannot evacuate all of them all at once because we dont have enough capacity on the boats.Its understandable they want to leave the Gilis, they are panicking.Some areas still hadnt been reached because rescuers have been slowed down by collapsed bridges, electricity blackouts and damaged roads.On Lombok, soldiers and other rescuers carried injured people on stretchers and carpets to evacuation centres, with many having to be treated outdoors because hospitals were too damaged.More terrifying footage showed screaming people running from their homes in Bali as cars and bikes rocked shook on the roads.Terrified tourists, including Barlow and supermodel Chrissy Teigen, took to Twitter to reveal their horror as tremors ripped through the island.Authorities issued a tsunami warning in the aftermath which covers North Lombok, East and North Bali, the north side of east Java, south-east Madura, south Kalimantan, and south Sulawesi.Barlow had been unwinding in a peaceful retreat by meditating, pictures of which he had shared with fans on Instagram who then became worried when news broke of the quake.After his ordeal, he tweeted: Thank you for your concern - we’re all fine - a bit shaken up.The quake was felt for several seconds in Bali, where people ran out of houses, hotels and restaurants.All the hotel guests were running so I did too. People filled the streets, said Michelle Lindsay, an Australian tourist.A lot of officials were urging people not to panic.Model Chrissy Teigen, who is in Bali, was live tweeting in the aftermath of quake, reporting: Bali. Trembling. So long.Moments earlier she had written: MASSIVE earthquake.Dazed and confused, she then walked out of her home clutching her baby while undressed.Other witnesses said the quake got stronger over several seconds and rattled windows and doors in their frames.Brit holidaymaker Reuben Messam, from Bedfordshire, told Sun Online he was in a small village of Bedugul in Bali.He said:  We were eating dinner when the quake occurred then suddenly the floor started to shake,  people started to panic. I saw people running towards the door.But then someone started to shout get under the table and then glasses of beer were falling off.The waiters and the waitresses said they were scared as it is very rare to have one this big..Tourist Hannah Small told : We are saying in Ubud, our whole hotel was shaking and parts of the ceiling and walls were falling down.It was awful, we rushed from the third floor to reach safety!Like Bali, Lombok is known for pristine beaches and mountains.Hotels and other buildings in both locations are not allowed to exceed the height of coconut trees.Indonesia is prone to earthquakes because of its location on the Pacific Ring of Fire, an arc of volcanoes and fault lines in the Pacific Basin.In December 2004, a massive magnitude 9.1 earthquake off Sumatra island triggered a tsunami that killed 230,000 people in a dozen countries.

title: jacob rees mogg home vandalised
story: The yobs — thought to be anti-Brexit anarchists — sprayed “scum” in white paint on his wife’s green Land Rover.A dildo covered with a condom was then stuck on the bonnet, alongside an anarchist symbol.The phrases “****head and “shut up and die” were scrawled on the garage.The louts also wrote “posh scum” and “politics death” on a patio window at the Leave-supporting MP’s estate in West Harptree, Somerset.Another anarchist sign was sprayed on a bench and “t**t” written on a ­garden umbrella stand.Condoms were strewn on the lawn and left hanging from a small cross.The vandals struck last Wednesday night while Mr Rees-Mogg, 49, was on a family holiday in New York.His maid discovered the dildo and graffiti on Thursday morning.Avon and Somerset Police suspect the condoms are a nod to the Catholic MP’s anti-birth control views.Mr Rees-Mogg said: “It appears to be someone who can’t hold their drink — and probably not Catholic.However, it has all been cleared up so this drunken protest will not even have a short-term effect.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm urged to ban eating of dogs
story: An international canine welfare group fears immigration from the Far East is secretly spreading it across Europe. Despite widespread public revulsion with the habit elsewhere in the world, neither killing dogs to eat nor consuming their meat is illegal in Britain.A total ban on the import, trade and consumption of dog meat is about to be enacted across America by the US Congress next month after similar concerns about its increase there.The government is being urged to repeat the US ban here, and the move last night won the backing of a series of senior MPs. The World Dog Alliance will launch a nationwide campaign in the UK for a full ban on any interaction with dog meat in the Autumn.The WDA’s Kike Yuen told The Sun last night: “In the US, people who eat dog meat are mainly immigrants from Asia. With three million immigrants from East Asia in the UK, we cannot deny this situation exists here too”.Mr Yeun added: “We also believe legislation against dog meat in UK would provide us with strength to continue our work in Asia, as the UK could influence other countries to stop dog meat consumption. Most of them usually refused to do so with the excuse that there is no such law in Western countries”.It is still legal to kill dogs and eat them in the UK, as long as they are killed in a way that does not cause suffering. Though the practice has been taboo across much of Europe for a century, there is also no specific ban on buying or selling dog meat either.Dog lover and Foreign Office minister Sir Alan Duncan last night dubbed a full ban “absolutely right”. Sir Alan, who owns a prize-winning cockapoo called Noodle, said: “There is no need in the modern world for this disgusting habit. We should nip it in the bud now to make sure the practice never takes off here. A civilised country is decent to animals, so let’s be fully decent here.”The chair of the All-party Parliamentary Dog Advisory Welfare Group Lisa Cameron MP added: “I very much support a ban on dog meat consumption in the UK, and urge the Government to look at this as a matter of urgency. We must be culturally sensitive, but I do not believe the general public would approve of the practice at all.”The SNP MP added: “Dogs are sentient beings and we value them very highly as pets. The last thing we want is dog farms here”.An estimated 30 million dogs a year are slaughtered to be eaten, across China, the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia.In China, 20 per cent of the population still eat dog meat - some because of the superstitious belief that it is a health tonic - and the country accounts for half the annual slaughter.In South Korea, 60 per cent of people eat dog meat regularly, and 5 million dogs are slaughtered each year to feed their appetite. The Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs last night refused to comment.BRITAIN is a nation of dog-lovers.Our four-legged friends heroically work alongside our police, fire services and armed forces.They assist the disabled. And they provide unconditional love for millions.Now, leading dog charities have warned that the consumption of dog meat here is on the rise.This sick trend cannot continue.Campaigners are calling on the Government to outlaw it.But it is horrifying that this is not already the case.America will enact legislation next month to make it illegal there.Our Government must do the same.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: university top staff spending
story: As we reveal today, staff at 54 universities spent £204million in two years on company cards.University top brass have serious questions to answer.Students and taxpayers — who fund the majority of universities’ income — will rightly feel outraged at the grotesque details included in our probe.Universities serve today as get-rich-quick schemes for top staff.Third-rate colleges charge students the same as Oxford and Cambridge for Mickey Mouse degrees.Vice-chancellors pocket hundreds of thousands of pounds a year with salaries greater than the Prime Minister’s.Now it has been revealed staff get jollies on expenses, too.Meanwhile, the interest rates for students to pay back their £50,000 worth of debt is soon to rise to 6.3 per cent…Our university funding system is not working in the interests of students.It needs reforming ­— and quickly.BRITAIN is a nation of dog-lovers.Our four-legged friends heroically work alongside our police, fire services and armed forces.They assist the disabled. title: jeremy corbyn not fit pm
story: The ugly barb is a knee-jerk term of abuse favoured by the Left, usually accompanied by “fascist” — or “Nazi” if Ken Livingstone’s anywhere nearby.So it is richly amusing to see Jeremy Corbyn publicly embraced by the Ku Klux Klan as a fellow Jew-hater.It takes one to know one.Jezza has at least done us all a favour by coming out as a genuine lifelong racist and proving he is unfit to hold any proper job, let alone as Prime Minister of this country.Helpfully, he has also exposed Labour’s own enduring hypocrisy in selectively deciding who and what is “racist”. Only whites qualify.For decades, the likes of Harriet Harman have led the crusade for equality, attacking men as oppressors and demanding — rightly — that women must be protected from abuse.Harman famously refuses even to endorse marriage as the best foundation for raising a family, let alone as a good thing in itself, a public commitment.Yet she and the overwhelming majority of virtue- signalling Labour MPs are silent, for instance, on the treatment of some Muslim women by some Muslim men.I can’t recall a Labour street protest against forced ­marriage or honour killings even though they are commonplace here and reprehensible in any society. Even the Home Office feels cowed when dealing with victims.Indeed, Labour turned on its own brave MP Sarah Champion for daring to raise the issue of rampant sex-trafficking by “mainly Pakistani men”.On the Left, racism trumps rape. Now, like the “F-word”, it has become the reach-for term of abuse applied to any debate — including the issue of Britain leaving the European Union.Opposition to the EU’s ­corrupt and undemocratic “Grand Projet” long precedes the uncontrolled mass immigration unleashed by Labour.Illegal immigration is simply another symptom of EU “we know best” arrogance — personified by German Chancellor Angela Merkel.Yet preposterous Tory MP Anna “Suck-It-Up” Soubry routinely slurs 17.4million referendum voters as “racist”.It is the mantra of all those who see Brexit voters — more than half the country — as thick and nasty.Odious Peter Mandelson joined in last week, avoiding the “R-word” but ludicrously accusing anyone who wants to leave the EU of “hating foreigners”, which is the same thing.“Nationalism is a hatred of foreigners,” says the slippery Euro peer. “They should not be confused with patriots.”“I voted Remain in the referendum though I entirely respect the contrary view of many others.”Mandy’s relationship with the truth has always been flaky, but this is pure cant.Even those who once worked alongside Lord Mandelson when Labour still stood for something are appalled.Ex-Home Secretary and fellow Remainer David Blunkett snapped yesterday: “The allegation that some of those voting for Leave were ‘racist’ is not a new one.“It has been bandied about and seems to me not only an insult to the many people that I used to represent who voted Leave, but also to utterly miss the point of why the majority of British people voted the way they did.“If we fail to understand, then we do ourselves, but crucially also our democracy, a great disservice.”Lord Blunkett also slammed Mandy’s call for a second referendum.He is right. It is now clear the mood has hardened against bullying Brussels.The EU’s own snide insinuations that voters here are racist “Little Englanders” has not helped.Bank of England boss Mark Carney, architect of Project Fear, sank the Pound last week by claiming chances of a clean-break Brexit were “uncomfortably high”.Trade Secretary Liam Fox warns the odds are now 60-40 against a deal.Remainers should understand that every gratuitous insult to the intelligence of decent British voters is another nail in Theresa May’s chances of a friendly ­negotiated settlement.McDonnell, cleverer than Corbyn, wants to stop Labour being dragged into what deputy leader Tom Watson calls a “vortex of eternal shame”. But McDonnell, too, is stained by anti-Jewish sentiment.In any case, Britain needs Jeremy Corbyn – to remain in place as the sullen figurehead of a blinkered Marxist rabble and remind voters what they are risking at the next election.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
