title: woman relationship ghost baby plans
story: Amethyst Realm even hopes to start a family with the romantic ghoul — who she met on a trip to Australia.The spiritual guidance counsellor, 30, ditched men to have sex with ghosts more than 11 years ago.But telling of her new love, Amethyst said: Its pretty serious. In fact, weve even been thinking about having a ghost baby. Speaking to New Idea, Amethyst told how the Aussie spectre crept up on her while she was out on a nature walk.She felt this incredible energy with the ghost — and immediately wanted to bed it.Amethyst added: I knew a new lover had arrived.The hunky ghost then followed her back to the UK and they have been a happy couple for the last six months.Hoping to move the relationship onto the next level, Amethyst said she now wants a baby with her ghostly lover.She admitted the idea sounds crazy but added: Ive been looking into it and I dont think its totally out of the question.Amethyst explained that phantom pregnancies — where signs like nausea and swelling of the abdomen are present in someone who is not pregnant — are actually ghost babies trapped in living people.She thinks that some women are able to conceive with a ghost — but are not able to go to term as their bodies cannot cope with the paranormal.Amethyst said: Im sure theres a way around that - I just havent worked it out yet.She seems primed to settle down with her one true ghoul after years of experimenting with multiple ghostly partners.Amethyst has had relationships with at least 15 different spirits since giving up on living men.And her choice has left her satisfied in the bedroom — as she orgasms when having sex with spirits.Asked if she could really climax during a sexual experience with a ghost, Amethyst said: For me, yes.Appearing on This Morning in December, Amethyst said: You can still feel it, its difficult to explain.Its like a weight but at the same time weightless and there was the physical things like the breath and stroking.And the energy as well, I think the energy was a lot to do with it. You feel a connection.

title: the tell tale signs someone is lying to you revealed by experts
story: The next time your partner seems to be hiding something or a friend makes excuses about why they can’t make your get-together, keep an eye on their body language and posture.In addition to slouching, liars will often shrink to make themselves appear smaller – and they may also lean away from the person they’re fibbing to.The insights were provided by therapist and behavioural specialist, Dr Sally Baker, who has teamed-up with MTV to mark the launch of its new show, True Love or True Lies, which premieres at 9pm on Monday 6th August.Other signs someone is lying include dilated pupils, being expressionless and mirroring movements – for instance, touching their hair as you do and taking a sip of a drink as you do.But contrary to widespread opinion, avoiding eye contact isn’t necessarily a sign someone is lying.Dr Sally Baker said: “Many people think a liar is unable to make eye contact.“However a liar is aware of this perception and may often make the effort to keep strong eye contact with whoever they are lying too.“The liar may also cross their legs so that their top leg blocks the person they are lying to - they also may sit with their back half turned towards the person they are lying to.”MTV also commissioned research of 2,000 UK adults which found three quarters admit they lie – typically 48 times a year.And when doing so, 55 per cent avoid eye contact, two in five are purposely vague with their responses and around one third tend to fidget.Three in 10 use mannerisms they wouldn’t normally use, more than one quarter talk differently to how they would ordinarily and 23 per cent take long pauses before answering any questions.But while 30 per cent think they are good at lying – just 15 per cent believe they could beat a lie detector.An honest 37 per cent believe it is NEVER okay to lie.2. The liar may lean away from the person they are lying to.3. The liar may cross their legs so that their top leg blocks the person they are lying to.4. The liar may sit with their back half turned towards the person they are lying to.5. The liar may well self-sooth to calm themselves by repeatedly touching their face or rubbing their forehead.The most common fib among those polled is simply stating everything is fine, followed by pretending to like a gift you’ve received.Saying you’re busy, lying about being stuck in traffic and saying you’re on your way round off the top five most common untruths.Researchers also found Brits tend to lie their partner most frequently, followed by their work colleagues and their boss.But our other halves are also the person we find it hardest to fib to.Dr Sally Baker, added: “Sometimes people lie to build themselves up - to have the advantage and their lies are self-serving.“Some people just lie all the time, small inconsequential lies that allow them to hide their true-self and they may be motivated by lack of self-esteem.2. That you liked a gift you received (when you didnt really)3. That youre busy4. That you were stuck in traffic (when you werent)5. Saying youre on your way when youve not left yet6. Why you were late for work7. That youre not drunk8. That youve done the housework9. Your age10. How many partners youve had11. That youre not hungry12. Calling into work poorly (when youre fine)13. When you lost your virginity14. That youll be back home on time15. That youre not expecting/dont want a gift16. How that scratch got on your car17. That youll call someone right back18. Liking your partners outfit19. How much you earn20. The job you do“Lying can be habit forming though and can become normalised over time.“Some people’s lies are survival strategies that require them to weave an ever more complex web of lies that interconnect with their previous lies.“That’s exhausting, and if you listen to their story, you might well be able to catch out inconsistencies.For more information about MTVs True Love or True Lies click here.

title: true story dai llewellyn face
story: His elastic jaw allowed him to pull a face as grotesque as it was hilarious — making him a perfect subject for cheeky postcards that were sent from seaside resorts across Britain.But despite his cartoonish demeanour, the true story behind this champion gurner tells of a quiet but colourful life in rural Wales.Dai Llewelyn kept locals in the small town of Mountain Ash, Cynon Valley, entertained with his rubber-faced antics over his 87 happy years there.Born in 1896, Dai was interested in the arts and performing from an early age and even helped bring big acts to the remote area.His expert gurning got him on stages across the country — including a stint under the bright lights of Londons Hammersmith Palais.There he met singing icon Gracie Fields and in 1924 invited her back to Wales to perform for the coal-mining community in Mountain Ash.Such was his impact on her that the star agreed to return and perform again in 1938 at the small Mountain Ash Pavillion right at the height of her popularity.And Dais own talent - aided by his teeth loss in later years - would be recognised with several honours and accolades.Few awards surpassed his victory in the Ugly Duckling competition on the hit TV show The Golden Shot — hosted by the legendary Bob Monkhouse.But his runner up finishes in the World Gurning Championships — where competitors battle it out to pull the most hideous face possible — were also up there among his most impressive career highlights.He reached second place a total of three times in his illustrious face-bending career.But day-to-day Dai was more than happy to keep families giggling with appearances at carnivals and fairs in Cynon Valley.Local historian Bernard Baldwin said that the much-loved Mr Llewelyn was the master of make-believe”.He wrote in his book Mountain Ash Remembered: He figured prominently in every carnival ever held in the town, and year after year appeared in some costume that was original — and often unique.On one occasion he appeared as the Lord Mayor of Mountain Ash, fresh from the soup kitchen.“He appeared in a tattered suit, a battered top hat and wearing a chain of office.“On another occasion he appeared as Popeye — and nobody looked more like the famous sailor than Popeye himself!”His death in 1983, at the age of 87, was a blow to the community.But his legacy lives on as the World Gurning Championship continues to grow in prestige and competitor numbers.Taking place at the Egremont Crab Fair in the Lake District — which having been established in 1267 is one of the longest-running fairs in the world — the gurning contest is among its most popular events.Contestants have to put their heads through a horse collar and snarl like a dog, look savage, and distort their faces.If he knew today the impact he has had on the noble sport, Dai Llewelyn would be sure to crack a smile — no matter how ugly it was.

title: joel henry gang dip sheets
story: But if things had worked out differently, 26-year-old Joel would likely be competing in an entirely different arena – one where scorecards centre not on your sports prowess but stabbings and maiming.Young gang members call them dip sheets - a tally of the number of people they have stabbed.Gangsters refer to who is on their dip sheet in controversial drill raps, where rival postcode gangs use the gritty music genre to taunt their rivals and threaten whoever they plan on stabbing next.This was once Joel’s way of life too.In his early teens he was in a gang where stabbings, shootings, and crime were not just the norm but expected, while the creed he lived by was that protecting the honour of the fam – not just his own blood family but his fellow gang members – came first.Only when a friend was shot dead in front of him when he was 15 years old was he able to set his life on a different course.Joel’s story is one of those told in Channel 5 series Lawless Britain which looks at the gang culture sweeping Britain.It’s estimated that up to 70,000 people under 25 consider themselves part of a gang – with many of them paying a heavy price for their affiliations.In the last two years there has been a 40 per cent rise in the number of deaths from gang stabbings and feuding.In the series the heavily masked and disguised gang members are given cameras to film for themselves on the street to show what life is like on the inside.It’s chilling. As they handle their serrated blades the gang members – girls among them - boast that fast money is the goal, and that you live, and die, by the streets.They are mantras Joel recognises only too well. Raised in London - he doesnt want to say which part - alongside two older siblings by his single parent mum, he grew up in an environment saturated with gang culture.Family members I looked up to were deeply involved in gang culture, he tells Sun Online. I’d see them coming back with money and jewellery and I wanted some of that.By 13 he was fully involved. It’s just a natural transition. When you’re a kid you’re not saying ‘what am I in?’ - it just happens.You don’t see it as a gang – it’s family so whatever you need to do to help the family you do it, you clean the pot.The gang gave him a sense of belonging that was absent elsewhere. There’s a lot of love around you. I didn’t have a lot of male figureheads in my family so these men were my role models, showing me how to survive.But this education went hand-in-hand with casual violence in which carrying a knife was routine.From an early age I saw people getting stabbed, shooting, robbing, slapped, he says.Growing up in this lifestyle I knew I was going to die if I don’t carry one. It was a badge of honour. People asked what kind of knife you had – it was all mine is this number of inches long.His mum and older brother were unaware of his affiliations, although his sister knew.She knew I wasn’t an idiot and she always had my back. But in some ways it was a double life.Yet even as a young teen, Joel had his misgivings.There had been a few moments where I thought I’m getting in too deep. There was this gradual realisation that this life was going nowhere good, he says.A realisation cemented when, aged 15, he saw a friend shot dead in front of him at a party.Joel was talking to another friend when he heard the boom of the gunshot.I saw the guy he was shooting at, his head just went straight back and he flew back and he was not moving on the floor.He didn’t make it. And I just thought: you know what there must be more to this - it’s a cycle that’s never going to end.Breaking free was easier said than done though.It helped that my school shut down and I changed schools to an academy filled with the best basketball players with the country. I’d played a bit at my old school but when I saw the basketball scene in my new school I caught the bug.Gradually training started to replace the time he had spent with his gang, although he still saw them from time to time. There was a lot of pressure, he recalls.I’d go to a birthday party and you could feel the shift in the energy. It was all I don’t see you round here any more. The ties were loosening all the time but I knew how easily I could get pulled back in.At 16 he was chosen to play in a tournament in Virginia in the US - another turning point.Going there - you realise there’s this big world out there and I was just wow – I wanted more of it, he recalls.His coach was a big support. He sat me down and asked me what I wanted to do and where I wanted to be in five years, Joel recalls. I had never been asked that before. I had never looked ahead before, seen a future.It was the spur he needed. From then on basketball became my sole focus. I sweated blood and tears.Rain or shine I was practising. It was hard but rewarding too. Playing basketball you get a different kind of love – there’s this positive energy.Community college followed before, aged 22, Joel got an agent and started playing professional basketball, first in London and then for the Surrey Scorchers.Such was his talent that today Joel makes his living through dunk contests, putting on shows throughout the globe, from Romania to Russia, The Caribbean to the USA displaying his unique talents on the court.He knows is a world away from the streets where he used to live and to which he sometimes returns. There’s still a lot of love there for my fam. We’ve all grown up together and they respect that I’m chasing my dreams.It doesn’t stop him worrying about the next generation. I’ve got little nephews and nieces and I worry about how they are going to get on in this scary time we’re living in, he says.A time where the stakes seem ever higher.Fuelled by drill music - a form of rap which glorifies gang life, with videos displaying weapons, describing recent stabbings and issuing threats to rivals – the death toll among young teens continues to steadily rise.Meanwhile, one surgeon interviewed in Lawless Britain reveals that in the last decade attacks have become more calculated and brutal.The types of blades that are being used are more severe, there are serrated blades and the individuals seem to know here to attack people anatomically, how to attack to inflict life-changing injuries, he says.It comes as little surprise to Joel. It’s scary to hear that people want to act this way although I don’t think it’s anything new - I just think it’s more in your face, he says.Gang life is a lot more commercialised now – social media has given people easier bragging rights. Kids are trying to do it for sport, to make a name for themselves.Is there any way the tide of senseless violence can be stopped?A lot of kids are bored and lost - they haven’t got a passion, they don’t know what to do with themselves. Instead of putting more laws in place we need to give them opportunities.That’s the single biggest thing we could do. Because without hope they don’t have a chance of getting out.Joel of course knows this first hand. I’ve gained the world. And I want to say to other gangs: there’s a whole world out there they have to see - and it’s beautiful.Lawless Britain: Gangs, Knives, Killers - tonight at 10pm Channel 5Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lombok earthquake gary barlow tweets
story: He and model Chrissy Teigen were among the thousands of tourists on the paradise islands when the magnitude-7 quake struck last night, injuring 236 and damaging thousands of homes.Take That star Barlow, 47, shared footage of himself enjoying yoga and getting to work in a stunning lodge just days before the region was reduced to rubble.With aftershocks raising fears of even more casualties and a tsunami warning in place, many tourists headed straight for the airport to avoid disaster.With the exodus underway, Barlow wrote on Twitter: I bumped into so many British families leaving Bali. How lucky we are to have that choice.I’ve had the misfortune of being in 7 earthquakes but none have felt more deep and raw as last nights. Followed by numerous after shocks. Praying for everyone affected.What we know so far...Earlier today, he posted a picture of himself on Instagram and said: Thank you Bali for such a peaceful and meaningful break.Such a shame it all came to an abrupt end. Praying for the beautiful people of this region who’ve been affected by the Earthquake.It is unclear which earthquakes the world-renowned singer-songwriter has been involved in and Sun Online could find no reporting of his previous brushes with death.While he and others headed home, more than 1,000 holidaymakers were left stranded on the Gili islands today in shocking Dunkirk-style scenes.Shocking footage showed a mad scramble to board tiny boats off Gili Trawangan where they had been stranded overnight.British teacher James Kelsall, 28, described scenes of utter chaos on nearby Gili Trawangan where Navy officers allegedly kicked locals to stop them climbing on boats.Kelsall, from Woodford Green in London, said more than holidaymakers were stranded on the palm-fringed island off the coast of Lombok for more than six hours today.Speaking from a beach as he awaited evacuation, he said: There was rumbling and then all the power went off. We ran to the beach to be clear of buildings which we could hear falling all around.Power and communications were severed in some areas, with landslides and a collapsed bridge blocking access to areas around the quake epicentre in the north.The military said it would send a ship with medical aid, supplies and logistics support.The tremor was powerful enough to be felt on the neighbouring island of Bali where, BNPB said, two people died. The first quake was also felt on Bali.

title: uk heatwave ghosts paranormal activity
story: One ghost hunter reported a major spike of calls in the past couple of months amid the ongoing summer scorcher.Professional paranormal investigator Gary Parsons, 53, said the ghostly apparitions have been summoned by the scorching sun.And some people have even been afraid to enter their own homes, he said.Gary, who runs Plymouth Paranormal Investigators (PPI) from his Devon home, believes the increase is due to the unseasonably warm weather the UK has been enjoying.He said: We have received a major spike in the number of calls during June and July, with people reporting scary supernatural phenomena.Have you seen any paranormal activity this summer? We want to hear from you! Call our reporter Neal Baker on 0207 782 4397 or email neal.baker@the-sunOne couple was almost afraid to go into their own home because of poltergeists, and residual energies making things move.Gary and his team of ghost hunters have been in the ghostly business for years and use highly specialised technical equipment to free homeowners from unwelcome spirits.Robert Bryant, technical paranormal expert, said: With temperatures soaring its having an unexplained increase in paranormal activities.We use a number of items to communicate with energies and especially our Huff Wonder Box.It is designed to search out unexplained orb lights, eerie voices, and deadly spirits.On a recent house investigation, my body was taken over by a dead priest and refused to leave until it was ordered to leave by my colleague Amanda Oriana.Today is the last day of soaring temperatures with intense rain and cloudy skies forecast from tomorrow onwards.But the fall in temperatures is thought to be a temporary blip — with the heatwave returning with a vengeance towards the end of August.The Met Office said: “For August-October, above-average temperatures are more likely than below-average.Have you seen any paranormal activity this summer? title: mystery sea creature alaska beach
story: Local fisherman discovered the washed-up creature and believed it to be a giant squid.Scientists from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Adminstration inspected the corpse of the globster  - a term used to describe a creatures with no visible eyes, no defined head, and no apparent bone structure - and revealed it to actually be a decaying humpback whale.Biologist Johanna Vollenweider, who inspected the corpse, understands why the fisherman might have misidentified the animal.She said: Fishermen mistook the animal as a giant squid likely because they could not get very close to it as it was hung up on a rocky reef very near the shore.The animal was highly visible to our gillnet fleet, which was actively fishing in the area. From a distance, the animal could look like a squid.She added: The body was very soft because it was so rotten and there were long, orange stripes along the body which are the pleats of the expandable throat of the humpback whale.Perhaps these looked like tentacles from afar.Fisherman first described the 30ft globster as having eyes the size of dinner plates.The eyes, however, were actually the rotting socket joint of the whales pectoral fin.Globsters have such a peculiar appearance because of how they deteriorate.The blubber gets real soft and gooey when it rots, said Vollenweider.The animal was also probably mutilated by hungry animals.The scientists suspect that the whale might have washed up on a beach and been eaten by eagles and brown bears.It is believed that the animal was killed by a ship strike - the evidence points towards blunt force trauma to the body.In May 2018, a 20ft globster washed up in The Philippines and many locals saw it to be an omen for impending doom.

title: surrey mansion for sale playhouse zip wire trampoline
story: The jaw-dropping Pinewood House in Oxshott, Surrey, also features a 50ft ballroom, two swimming pools, cinema, bar, gym, sauna and a steam room.For gearheads it also offers an underground garage that has parking for 20 cars.And Londoners who dont want to move too far from the capital need not worry as you can see as far as Canary Wharf that is 20 miles away thanks to its observatory tower.During the First World War the Grade II listed property was owned by shipping magnate Arnold Trinder, whose fleet of ships was instrumental in breaking the German U-boat blockade.The house still has some maritime features paying tribute to Trinders time at the property.However by the 1950s it had been subdivided into three properties and was in a poor state of repair.Polish builder Andrew Holeshowski bought one of the three for less than £500,000 in 1993 and by 2007 he had bought up his neighbours properties too.Mr Holeshowski embarked on a three-year £10m renovation project to turn Pinewood back into a single home and restore its grandeur.Period features, including a fresco depicting scenes of Miltons Paradise Lost in the drawing room, have been restored.The dramatic double height Great Hall has intricately carved wooden pillars and an impressive carved stone fireplace while the ballroom has gold leaf hand-painted ceiling plasterwork and the walls of the bathroom attached are also covered in the same 24K gold leaf.The impressive home is also fitted with air conditioning, underfloor heating and dozens of hidden speakers providing music throughout the house.In total the house has 28,501 sq ft of accommodation over four floors with a grand galleried reception hall, drawing room, sitting room, ballroom, library, formal kitchen, commercial kitchen with cool room and pantry.It also has a lounge bar, wine cellar, spa room, indoor swimming pool, steam room, sauna, gym, a choice of two master bedroom suites with a dressing room and en suite bathroom, seven further bedrooms and bathrooms, an Art Deco style cinema room with triple screen and a bar area.There is also staff accommodation within the house and a separate four-bedroom cottage that could be used for guests or staff.Its hilltop position gives the house views over Crown Estate land - woodland, green fields and as far as London landmark buildings on the horizon.And the unique home is just as impressive outside in the three acres of grounds. The manicured gardens are heart-shaped, it has extensive split level terracing and its own adventure playground for the children.As well as the almost 6,000 sq ft underground car park, the house has outdoor parking for a further 15 cars by the terrace at the front of the house and there is additional staff parking for another 12 cars.Liz Berman, from Strutt and Parker, said: Pinewood House is an amazing property. Its a very grand house that sits on top of the hill, encompassed by its own gardens and not overlooked at all.Its got everything you could want and everything is immaculate. The lawns are perfectly manicured.Its definitely a London retreat, Oxshott is about 25 minutes into Waterloo station. Its very popular as that first step when people are looking to move out of London but dont want to be fully in the countryside.If you still want that civilised suburban feel this is perfect, but you are within minutes of open countryside.The house speaks for itself really, youll either love it or hate it. Its one of those houses that is very special and well known in Oxshott because it is quite grand.Even if you dont sell it to the parents, youll definitely convince the children with the incredible playhouse. The owners spent a fortune building that and its just an amazing thing.You cant keep the kids off it - its on an elevated level and has got a safety surface, its like a professional assault course.For the adults there is a beautiful indoor pool, which you can open up to the terrace, and for anyone who has a big car collection this would be perfect. It has an incredible underground parking with spaces for 20 cars.

title: ethiopia mursi tribe lip stretching discs
story: Females of the Mursi Tribe, in Ethiopia, wear the discs to portray their social and economic importance within their community.They carve their own patterns and designs into them and can even upgrade the size as they get older.These amazing photographs of the tribe, who live in a secluded reserve, were captured by 38-year-old tour operator Evi Aryati Arbay from Jakarta, Indonesia.Holding their children and standing outside straw huts, the women try to smile for the camera in the stunning snaps.Mr Arbay said: The Mursi tribe were a truly fascinating group.The incredible lip discs are worn by their women, while the men have scars on their shoulders that represent how many enemies they have killed during encounters with intruders in their territory.You cannot enter the reserve without an armed guard.The Mursi girls use lip discs on the lower lip from an early age - around seven to 15 years old or before they get married.The smaller discs are made from wood and they can upgrade to a clay disc once they are an adult.The Mursi are among the last groups in Africa for whom it is still the norm for women to wear such discs.Surrounded by mountains between the Omo River and its tributary the Mago, the home of the Mursi is one of the most isolated regions of the Ethiopia.

title: nearly one in 12 rank and file cops have to take second job to make ends meet survey finds
story: The poll of more than 27,000 personnel by the Police Federation of England and Wales put the figure at 7.8 per cent, up 1.5 per cent on last year.Police are allowed second jobs outside working hours with approval from their force.The Federation, which represents officers from constable up to chief inspector, blamed the rise on low pay. Its survey found that 44.8 per cent worry about the state of their personal finances almost every day, 11.8 per cent hardly ever had enough money to cover all essentials and 3.8 per cent took out a payday loan last year.Federation boss John Apter said: “Our members are clearly suffering from even worse financial pressures than last year, with some appearing to be in dire straits.“Our members are under immense pressure to deliver, with dwindling resources and rising crime, leading to a demand for our services that has never been higher. All they want is to be adequately paid for the job that they do.”Last month, the Government announced a two per cent pay rise for officers, but the Federation branded that “derisory”.But the news that one in 12 have second jobs suggests that not all of the wailing about long hours and working conditions are entirely legitimate.The next time a victim is told there’s nobody available to investigate, they might wonder what their local bobbies are up to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fog fogbank advection lands end cornwall
story: The huge fogbank appeared off Lands End at around noon on Friday as temperatures in the UK peaked at 33C.The photos may look dramatic but according to the Met Offices Craig Snell this type of meteorological event is not that uncommon.Advection fog is caused when two different types of air mix, causing the hotter air to cool rapidly and condense, forming the thick wall of fog.Mr Snell told The Sun Online: Its fairly common and not unusual.It mostly occurs in spring but can happen at most times in the year.In this case the warm air coming off the land and mixing with the cooler sea air.Instagram user chefinmyhomecornwall wrote on their page: Remember this happening whiles surfing down Gwynver a while back, spooky and stunning.John George added: Yes, beautiful, I witnessed something similar on the east coast - Bempton cliffs. You have to be there to fully appreciate, great photo.Britain basked in soaring temperatures today but there looks to be a break in the heatwave from tomorrow with rain and cloudy skies forecast.It comes after people enjoyed 30C highs over the weekend with thousands flocking to parks, beaches and enjoying BBQs at home.Thunderstorms are set to make a return on Tuesday and Wednesday in the South.Torrential downpours, lightning, hail and gusty winds could cause travel disruption across the country.However, the fresher and wet outlook for the UK isn’t set to last for long.Some forecasts say the weather could break on Wednesday or even earlier on Tuesday evening.

title: next labour leader odds replace jeremy corbyn
story: Here we take a look at who could take over as the next leader if Jeremy Corbyn was to be ousted, or step down, from the top spot.The favourites include Emily Thornberry, as well as fellow shadow cabinet members Angela Rayner, Keir Starmer and Rebecca Long-Bailey, while Mr Corbyn’s right-hand man John McDonnell has long been seen as a leader-in-waiting.Alex Apati from bookmakers Ladbrokes said: With 3 of the top 4 runners being female and Emily Thornberry the clear 5/1 favourite, its looking increasingly likely that a woman will take over from Jeremy Corbyn as Labours next leader.Asked about where punters are putting their money, he told The Sun: Over the last week the two most popular selections with punters have been Rebecca Long Bailey and John McDonnell, with the latter possibly being viewed as Corbyns preferred replacement if he was to step down.“There has also been some money for David Miliband over the last few days, in from 33/1 to 25/1.Here we profile the runners and riders:Becoming Labour leader would be the culmination of a remarkable turnaround for the woman booted out of Ed Miliband’s shadow cabinet after her sneering tweet about a house with a white van and an England flag back in 2014.She has somehow managed to shed her New Labour image, and despite being the wife of a millionaire High Court judge, has become a senior player in the Corbyn administration.The MP for Islington South, the next door constituency to Jeremy Corbyn’s, has impressed when deputising for him at Prime Minister’s Questions in recent months.She could be a uniting figure, but would need to be endorsed by the left if she is to win a vote among the Corbynista base.The shadow education secretary has a compelling back story – leaving school with no qualifications as a pregnant teenager, working her way up to the shadow cabinet.Having only become an MP in 2015 she has no baggage to carry within the party, and has been unflinchingly loyal to Mr Corbyn.A former care worker and union official, and now a grandma at 38, she has failed to make an impression outside of Westminster in the past two years.But Mr Corbyn himself has admitted she could “absolutely” become leader, when asked about her and fellow rising star Rebecca Long-Bailey.The shadow Brexit secretary and former director of public prosecutions has won many admirers for his forensic examinations of David Davis over the Government’ Brexit plan in the House of Commons.But he has frequently been at odds with the leader’s office over what direction Labour should be doing in with regards our EU exit, and would potentially make the party more pro-Remain.And the Holborn MP has failed to back Labour’s new anti-Semitism code, urging the party to “reflect” on the row and repair relations with the Jewish community.An uncharismatic and somewhat dreary public speaker, it seems unlikely he would inspire the grassroots in the way the current leader has, but is respected among Labour MPs.Another of the 2015 intake tipped to take over, the Salford MP is seen as John McDonnell’s protégé – once calling her part of the “next generation of our socialist leadership”.If the shadow chancellor doesn’t run himself he could be a powerful backer of the 38-year-old shadow business secretary.But while she is becoming more accomplished as a media performer she has no name recognition at all among the wider public, however she would be seen as ideologically sound by fans of Mr Corbyn.Long seen as Mr Corbyn’s natural successor, the shadow chancellor’s odds have widened since last year’s election.The 66-year-old firebrand is a firm favourite of Labour members but there have recently been splits between him and his boss on policy and presentation – calling for the investigation into Margaret Hodge to be dropped.He recently hired a new press spokesman, prompting speculation he was eyeing up the role, but would potentially only be a stop-gap before handing over to one of the younger Corbyn acolytes.Would also bring a lot of baggage, given his positive comments about the IRA.A former shadow cabinet member, she resigned in protest at Mr Corbyn’s leadership in June 2016 along with a raft of other MPs.Seen as being on the “soft left” wing of the party, the Wigan MP has been tipped as a potential leader if the party is to be dragged back towards the centre.An accomplished media performer, she was a strong campaigner during the “Pestminster” harassment scandal, but would only have a chance of winning a vote of the membership if the Corbynite vote was split between two candidates.Has built his own power base since swapping Parliament for City Hall in 2016 to become Mayor of London.Strongly anti-Brexit, he has been outspoken of a raft of issues, and is one of only a few Labour politicians with nationwide recognition, but has often angered Corbynistas.The recent crime spate in the capital has damaged his reputation, and he has already said he plans on seeking another term – keeping him away from Westminster until at least 2020 if not 2024.Failed in her bid to be leader once before, the former Cabinet minister would struggle to win over the membership given her history with the Blair and Brown governments.She is well-respected in Westminster, and has won plaudits for her work taking on Theresa May and other ministers on various committees – helping push Amber Rudd to resign over Windrush.But unless the party moves back to the centre that seems to be as far as she can go, while her husband Ed Balls waltzes his way to becoming a light entertainment star. The Blairite’s Blairite, the Streatham MP has carved out a career as Labour’s most pro-EU campaigner, spearheading the push for a second referendum to reverse Brexit.If the negotiations with Brussels go badly and public opinion swings wildly in favour of staying in the bloc then he has an outside chance of leading a Remain-backing party.But in every other area of policy the slick media performer would be seen as wildly too right-wing for the Corbynistas.For years seen as some kind of “prince across the water” by the party’s Blairite wing, he has been working for a charity in America since exiting British politics in 2012.The former Foreign Secretary, has long hinted at a return to Westminster, but would find a very different party to the one he left behind after being beaten to the leadership by his brother Ed.His candidacy would be a non-starter for a number of reasons not least because he isn’t an MP, and even his erstwhile supports see him as yesterday’s man. He would be routed in a vote by the members.

title: parents should limit kids to maximum of two hours screen time a day in bid to boost their health
story: Mums and dads are being urged to set an example by cutting back their own use of phones, computers and TVs.The doctors even suggest banning these devices from bedrooms and at meal times.Socialising more as a family outdoors can also lead to reduced screen time and provide additional benefits, they add.A panel of medics from the American Heart Association issued the advice after reviewing existing studies on screen use and health.They say that youngsters aged eight to 18 now spend more than seven hours a day staring at a screen.Time spent in front of the television is falling, but it is outweighed by use of phones, tablets and computers for social media, watching videos, playing games and  browsing the internet.This means that more people are leading a sedentary life — which raises the risk of obesity, heart attacks and strokes.Dr Tracie Barnett, who chaired the panel, said: “When possible, all screen-based activities should be reduced to mitigate risks.“Passive consumption of screens should be avoided, such as leaving the television on in the background, to avoid normalising this behaviour.“We advise all children to ‘sit less, play more’.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: longest serving poppy seller rosemary powell mbe 103
story: Rosemary Powell, 103, was just six years old when she sold poppies for the first ever appeal in 1921 - three years after the First World War ended.She sold her first poppies on Richmond Bridge with her mum and has done so ever since - even making her own poppies when living in Africa as a missionary.The great-grandmother from London hung up her collecting tin after this years appeal - and was handed her MBE at her nursing home on Monday.Rosemarys son, Giles Powell, said: The presentation of the MBE has been one of the biggest moments in her life - and mum has lived a very full life.Its significant in what it represents in terms of both her loyalty and her commitment.She raised money for all those years due to the impact war had on her own family.She lost so many family members it really had an impact on her - it really was the catalyst for her volunteering work for The Royal British Legion.Its a really special day for us as a family and were so proud of her.Rosemarys father, Charles Ashton James - who served in the 126 Balluchi and Indian Army Regiment - was shot in the head and wounded during World War Ones Battle of the Somme.She also lost two godfathers and three uncles during the conflict.Her fiancé, Robin Ellis, died in 1944 when the Lancaster bomber he was flying in crashed near Inverness the day before their engagement was due to be announced in a national newspaper.Robin was a Commander in the Royal Navy, at the time the youngest Commander in the Service.Rosemary also lost her younger brother, Peter, a Major in the Army, during World War Two.During the Second World War, Mrs Powell trained as a voluntary aid detachment (VAD) nurse providing civilian nursing to the military.She lived in Africa for a year in the 1950s but made poppies out of paper to give to local people during Remembrance.During 20 years living in France, Mrs Powell and her Royal Navy officer husband Selwyn sold blue cornflowers - the French equivalent to UK poppies.Rosemary sold poppies at Kings Mall shopping centre in Hammersmith, London, and other areas of London prior to that.Despite moving to a nursing home in Chiswick in 2015 aged 101, Rosemary continued collecting for the Poppy Appeal, selling poppies to her fellow residents.She was included in this years Queens Birthday Honours List for voluntary service to the Royal British Legion Poppy Appeal.She sat in a wheelchair draped in a poppy-patterned blanket, was handed the MBE on behalf of the Queen by the Vice Lord-Lieutenant of Greater London, Colonel Jane Davis.Her sons Antony, Giles and Nicolas as well as granddaughters Emma and Rachel Powell and Celia Speller attended the ceremony at St Marys Convent and Nursing Home in Chiswick on Monday.Charles Byrne, Director General of The Royal British Legion, said: Rosemary is truly inspirational and she is most deserving of this honour.Our volunteers go to extraordinary lengths to raise funds to support our Armed Forces community, those who are serving, those who have served, and their families. Rosemary is a shining example of that extraordinary commitment.Over the decades Rosemary has helped to change the lives of thousands of Armed Forces personnel, veterans, and their families, and that is a legacy to be truly proud of.Rosemary is most deserving of this honour, and everyone at the Legion wishes her a very happy retirement.

title: teen girls double social media self harm
story: The number of hospital admissions for girls jumped from 7,327 in 1997 to 13,463 last year. Those being treated for an attempted overdose rose more than ten-fold — from 249 in 1997 to 2,736.As far as I am concerned, social media is almost entirely responsible.In a world where everyone relies on their phones for everything, there has never been a more worrying time for mental health.To be a teenage girl in this day and age is to be never alone — and always lonely.They are spending day after day wading through airbrushed photos of images society has deemed perfect.Whether it is a member of the Kardashian family posing with a diet pill, a boob job advert in the middle of Love Island or a photo of a friend with whitened teeth and smooth skin, our screens are filled with how we can be better — with how we SHOULD be better.Jon Goldin is vice chairman of the child and adolescent faculty at the Royal College of Psychiatrists.He  said recently: “There are a range of factors putting pressure on young children — academic pressure, exam pressure, social media . . . with fear of missing out and comparing yourself unfavourably to images you see online.“If you look at social media, my hunch is that girls are probably more sensitive to some of those factors than boys.”Although suicide is still the biggest killer of men under 45, awareness of this is at an all-time high. Hospital admissions for self-harm in boys, while still too high (2,236 last year), are stable.There was a campaign (which I took part in) two weeks ago that went viral on Instagram as people were asked to signal that they were OK as a means of opening a conversation on mental health.It is a conversation that desperately needs to be had.Despite massive steps to raise awareness, not least the Royal Family getting behind the Heads Together campaign for last year’s London Marathon, the internet — and young girls’ place in it — still needs a lot of talking about.I was lucky. Instagram was only invented when I was 16 and it did not matter a jot that I did not start using it until I was 18. Although we had social media, it was in its infancy, and I am incredibly grateful for that. My phone played a very small part in my life as a teenager.24% of girls are depressed by age 1480,000 UK kids suffer from severe depression90% of teen girls unhappy with their bodies70% of young people have been cyber-bulliedAs I went through the trials of being a young, insecure girl at school, negative thoughts were not able to follow me home. I would say goodbye to the bitching at 3.30pm and eat bangers and mash with my siblings without a thought for the girls in my class — no pinging from my phone to create waves of anxiety.These days that is simply not an option.Every issue that every teenager has ever faced is magnified to an extraordinary level with the advancement of technology.But removing phones from our daughters is simply not an option. Telling a teenager they can not have the internet is to tell them they can not have friends.Ten years ago a teenage friendship could withstand a summer holiday of no contact, but now a weekend with no signal, a Tuesday night with no Instagram story, makes kids hyperventilate.To be offline is to be forgotten. It is not showing up to the only party. The party that is going on all day and, more worryingly, all night too.Self-harm is, more often than not, a cry for help.As the internet forces its way into every corner of our lives, I cannot help but feel that it is a cry for human attention for affectionate, real-life attention.Warning signs  include if a child starts talking about themself in terms of failure or if there is a  change in their eating or sleeping patterns.Try asking  open-ended questions and do not give up if they are reluctant to  respond.Do not ban social media but set a good example and do activities away from it together.If you are affected by any of the issues raised in this article, please call the Samaritans (free) on 116 123.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: putins ally predicts terrible conflict if georgia joins nato
story: Georgias NATO ambitions have been a source of anger for Russia which fought a war with its southern neighbour in 2008.NATO leaders promised Georgia it would one day join the alliance, which Russia regards as a hostile military bloc.It (Georgias entry to NATO) could provoke a terrible conflict. Its not clear why this is needed, Medvedev told Russias Kommersant FM radio station.Medvedevs comments comes weeks after President Vladimir Putin warned NATO against cultivating closer ties with Ukraine and Georgia.He said such a policy was irresponsible and would have unspecified consequences for the alliance.Russian forces entered two breakaway Georgian regions in 2008, which remain garrisoned by Russian troops to this day.Moscow says its presence is in keeping with local peoples wishes, but which the West and the Georgian government calls an illegal occupation.NATO leaders discussed ties with Georgia at their summit in Brussels in July.Prominent Georgian politicians are keen for their country to join the Western military alliance, but have seen chances of joining hampered by Russian territorial incursions.Under NATO rules, countries with territorial conflicts cannot join NATO.

title: christmas mp brexit
story: Solicitor General Robert Buckland said time is now “very tight” and MPs will be “working overtime” to deal with the massive workload.Mr Buckland, who is in charge of drawing up some of the new laws, also told BBC Radio 4’s Westminster Hour: “We’re going to perhaps have to look at a few recesses and actually the time that we use in Parliament in order to make sure that everything is thoroughly debated”.With just six months of Parliamentary sitting time left before Brexit day on March 29, the government faces a mad dash to pass a raft of key new laws.They include the Withdrawal Agreement and Implementation Bill – which can only be introduced once any deal is done with Brussels.The Lords still also have to pass the Trade Bill and Customs Bills, which could see weeks of bitter fights with the Commons still.Under a no deal scenario, at least three extra bills would also need to be passed through both houses for the nation to keep functioning - the Immigration Bill, the Agriculture Bill and the Fisheries Bill.Downing Street didn’t disagree with Mr Buckland’s warning.The PM’s official spokesman would only say: “The bills will be debated by MPs in the usual way”.It came as a leaked police document warned a no-deal Brexit poses a substantial risk to public safety.The national body of police and crime commissioners wrote to the Home Secretary over fears police officers will instantly losing vital access to cross-border investigative powers and databases if the UK was to crash out of the EU in March.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beyonce im embracing my curves after second childbirth
story: She told Vogue: "After the birth of my first child, I believed in the things society said about how my body should look."I put pressure on myself to lose all the baby weight in three months, and scheduled a small tour to assure I would do it."Looking back, that was crazy."She explained her second pregnancy, in which she carried twins Rumi and Sir, she was swollen from toxemia (pre-eclampsia), and had to take a month's bed rest. Her health was in danger and she was given an emergency caesarean.She added: "During my recovery, I gave myself self-love and self-care, and I embraced being curvier.The former Destiny's Child frontwoman said she is prepared to go into "beast mode" when she wants to see a six-pack again, but has no problems enjoying her figure in the meantime.Beyonce's interview in the September edition also marks the first time an African-American photographer has shot the cover for the publication.She explained she wanted to use her influence to support other artists, and choosing 23-year-old Tyler Mitchell was a step to ensuring "everyone's voice counts". title: europe really doesnt need us as much as we need them
story: They reveal something not just about his own thinking but about the Leavers he represents too.It is connected to the oft-repeated mantra that "they need us just as much as we need them".It is one of the phrases of our Brexit-infused age, one which the public has adopted and repeats themselves.That they do is because it speaks to their own conception of British statecraft - the public views the EU/UK battle as one of two equal powers.As painful as it might be for us to accept, it is not.Yes the UK is the EU's second-largest economy. Yes it is its largest military player. Yes we are a cultural powerhouse. Yes we are their biggest individual market. Britain is powerful - but the EU is more powerful than we are.On paper - this should not be surprising, yet no politician, of any stripe, would ever dare say it.But the facts speak for themselves: We are 65 million of a bloc of 450 million. Ours is a $2.9trn (&#1632.2trn) economy, they are $19trn (&#16314.6trn) They represent 44% of our exports. We, just 9% of theirs. They are 27 - we are one.The impact of a no deal (as all the studies show) would be considerable but they have a crucial advantage: they are able to spread the risk and burden. For that reason, the same studies show, it would hurt us far more. We have nowhere else to turn.This should not be surprising. Imagine another country taking Britain's place - that we had 'Frexit' or 'Nexit' or 'Spexit' or even 'Deutschexit', ask yourself where the power would lie. It would be with the remaining states of the union.That we struggle to come to terms with that is, I think, deeply revealing of the British psyche.This imbalance was obscured through years of membership - we had no need to confront our own relative weakness as a member of the club - but now we are outside, that asymmetry of power is exposed for all to see.That is why we have accepted concession after concession, not because of Theresa May's pusillanimity but because of the hard truths of realpolitik.That is why Mrs May and her ministers have been conducting a grand tour of Europe. Not because they want yet more sea bass and asparagus in yet another state dinner, but because they recognise how powerful they are as a bloc and how isolated we are in their face.They want to tear them asunder, to divide and conquer - this is what David Davis said would happen during the referendum. Yet, they have remained, in 18 months a united set of two, while our own house, our own government, has been fatally divided.Time and again throughout our history, Britain has acted to prevent the emergence of a hegemonic power which controlled all of Europe, aware that Britain, even with an empire, could not resist a united continent's gravitational pull. Today's crop of politicians, seem to have forgotten that lesson. Looked at through the psychology of the British public's collective psyche, we can see Mrs May as the Wizard of Oz - less powerful than her people think, or than our population would like others to believe.That is what is invidious about Brexit for British politicians - for the British public to accept Chequers, or something like it, would essentially be to ask the British people to accept a downgrade of their own view of British power, a downgrade of the sort of country we think we should be and that we think we are.We are not an especially jingoistic nation, but that is much to stomach. It is a view which, however unfair, would be repeated and churned by the exact Brexiteers who, from Mrs May's point of view, forced us to accept the downgrade in the first place.

title: liam fox faces ridicule over u turn on brexit no deal
story: So what has changed? A lot, actually. The Chequers deal has bombed with Tory MPs and activists, including members of the PM's own association in Maidenhead.Two senior cabinet ministers, David Davis and Boris Johnson, have resigned, with Mr Davis's former lieutenants Steve Baker and Stewart Jackson now acting as pro-Brexit attack dogs.Mr Johnson, meanwhile, is now firmly re-installed as the darling of the Tory grassroots and the hot favourite with the activists to replace Mrs May as party leader and prime minister.Then there has been the reaction to the Chequers deal from Michel Barnier, accused by Dr Fox in his Sunday Times interview of "intransigence" and of making no deal more likely. In his lofty, patrician manner and with customary "hauteur", Mr Barnier picked the Chequers plan apart clause by clause, to the extent that even its biggest fans fear it is now mort dans l'eau.And that's one reason why Theresa May was probably wasting her time when she went to the French president's Riviera retreat and told him Brussels faces a choice between the Chequers deal and no deal.When I went to Strasbourg for Emmanuel Macron's address to the European Parliament in April, I was told by senior MEPs that the president and Mr Barnier are extremely close politically.As a result, President Macron - probably the EU's chief powerbroker now that Angela Merkel's authority is waning - will ensure that his "uncle" succeeds Jean-Claude Juncker as president of the European Commission next year.No wonder President Macron told Mrs May at Napoleon's stronghold of Fort Bregancon that he was not willing to break the Brexit deadlock by breaking ranks with the EU's negotiators."There is absolutely no intention to speak in place of Monsieur Barnier," a French diplomat was reported to have said, confirming the president's close alignment with Mr Barnier.And so in spite of Mrs May's Riviera charm offensive, there has at the same time been a significant change in tone in the government's Brexit language in recent weeks, as the Chequers plan has faced derision and rejection. First there has been what Brexiteers claim has been a return of "project fear" scare stories, about stockpiling of food and medicines, lorry gridlock at Dover, long queues at border control and customs and fees for travel visas.But the biggest change in tone has come in the Foreign Office, where Boris Johnson's clown-like bluster and looseness with facts and detail have been replaced by the more thoughtful approach of Jeremy Hunt.Instead of Mr Johnson's gung-ho and cavalier approach to Brexit, former Remainer Mr Hunt has been deadly serious in his warnings of the risk of "no deal by accident" increasing by the day.Then last week, Bank of England governor Mark Carney - denounced as "the high priest of Project Fear" by Jacob Rees-Mogg - said the risk of no deal was "uncomfortably high and highly undesirable".Are all these dire warnings aimed at putting pressure on Brussels to sign up to a deal? Almost certainly. Will they work? Probably not. But then some hardline Brexiteers on the Tory backbenches have always favoured no deal.The danger for the prime minister, however, is that the more no deal looks likely the louder the calls from pro-Remain MPs and campaigners for a second referendum - a so-called "people's vote" - will become.

title: make the most of it before heatwave cools off
story: It follows a sweltering weekend across the UK where the hottest temperature of 30.2C (86.36F) was recorded in Northolt, Greater London, on Sunday.The mercury is set to rise past 30C (85F) in parts of the UK on Monday, with 33C (91F) possible in London and to the east of the capital, the Met Office said.A level three heat health warning for the South East was issued as a result, with a 90% chance of heatwave conditions for the region between Monday and Wednesday. Temperatures could edge a degree higher on Tuesday, potentially peaking at 34C (91.4F) in Essex or Norfolk.Last week, records were smashed in eight areas of Portugal, while Lisbon broke a 37-year-old record with thermometers reaching 44C (111.2F) on Sunday.British holidaymakers abroad have been warned to avoid spending time in the sun during the hottest part of the day and to keep hydrated as temperatures remain especially high in some European countries.Red health alerts for extreme heat have been issued for more than half of Portugal, with thermometers passing 46C (114.8F) over the weekend. The hot, dry conditions have led to several wildfires.

title: ben stokes affray trial footage
story: NewsBen Stokes affray trial: Footage shown to jury of 'drunk' cricketer punching two men when he 'lost control'Stokes, 27, denies a charge of affray and insists his show of force in Bristol city centre, caught on video, was "reasonable and justified"Share&nbspByAdam AspinallRod MinchinClaire Hayhurst20:07, 6 AUG 2018Updated01:01, 7 AUG 2018NewsIn the footage Stokes can be seen punching two men (Image: Avon and Somerset Police)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEngland cricket star Ben Stokes can be seen punching two men in a video showed to the court at his affray trial today. The 27-year-old all-rounder is accused of punching Ryan Hale, 27, to the ground and then allegedly knocking out Ryan Ali, 28, a short time later during a fracas in the early hours of September 25 last year. A jury at Bristol Crown Court heard that Stokes mocked a gay couple and verbally abused a bouncer before knocking out the two men. Stokes, 27, “lost control” after a boozy night out in a club, it was alleged. He appeared in court yesterday with Ali, 28, and Hale, 27, who were both punched by the sportsman. The first day of their affray trial heard that “aggressive” Stokes knocked out Army veteran Hale then put fireman Ali in hospital with a fractured eye socket. But England all-rounder Stokes insisted his use of force was “reasonable and justified”, and claimed the brawl was sparked by “nasty homophobic language” by the two men he floored. All three co-defendants deny affray. Prosecutor Nicholas Corsellis told the jury Stokes’ violence was “not a trivial moment of unpleasantness” and that the star “lost his control” and attacked out of “revenge or retaliation”. The violence erupted in Bristol city centre last September. Stokes and England teammate Alex Hales, 29, were out drinking in the hours after the team’s victory over the West Indies, while Ali and Hale were &shycelebrating a work promotion.  All four were in the Mbargo club in the city but did not bump into each other until the early hours when trouble began on a nearby street, the jury heard. Mr Corsellis said the cricketers returned to the nightclub after closing time at 2am and tried to get back in after they had left an hour earlier. The court was told doorman Andrew Cunningham refused them entry – despite the pair offering &pound60. Mr Corsellis said Stokes verbally abused the bouncer, telling him his gold teeth “make you look like a c***” and that his tattoos were “sh**”. CCTV footage played to the court showed Stokes outside the club with Mr Hales. Stokes allegedly began to mimic two gay men – Kai Barry and William O’Connor – who had just left the venue. Mr Corsellis said video showed Stokes throwing a cigarette butt at the Mr O’Connor’s head. The court was told the bouncer told Stokes: “If you are going to start on anyone, start on me.” Mr Corsellis said footage showed Stokes and Mr Hales “sharing a moment of hilarity” at the expense of Mr O’Connor, before Stokes tried to shake hands with the bouncer. When Mr Cunningham refused, Stokes was caught on camera gesticulating wildly. Mr Corsellis said: “It seemed to enrage him, the hand gestures, the head &shymovement back. It all needs to be viewed in the context of the doorman, the mimicking of an openly gay man, that sets out his state of mind… “Mr Stokes’ behaviour outside the club set a clear tone for what happened that night… He took to acting in a provocative and offensive way.”  Bristol crown court heard that Ali told police he and Hale met the gay couple in the club earlier in the evening and “had their bottoms felt” by one of them but that it was light-hearted. However, the jury was told CCTV showed Mr Barry touch Ali “inappropriately” in the groin area, prompting him to push Mr Barry away. The court heard that shortly afterwards Stokes became involved in the apparent altercation with Ali and Hale, later saying he was coming to the defence of Mr Barry and Mr O’Connor. Student Max Wilson recorded the brawl on his phone. He said the group acted “like football hooligans”. Mr Corsellis said: “He did not believe the initial shove came from either Mr Stokes or Mr Hales, but later in the incident he described how Mr Stokes continued to behave in an aggressive manner, ignoring Mr Hales’ attempts to calm him down.” In Mr Wilson’s footage a man’s voice is heard shouting “enough, enough”. The court was told Ali was seen holding a bottle, raising it and motioning as if to hit Mr Hales, but then striking out at Mr Barry. Hale and Ali seemingly tried to retreat but Stokes began throwing punches while Mr Hales told him “that’s enough”, the court was told. Mr Corsellis added: “There’s a big difference between using violence to defend someone and… violence to retaliate or to punish the person who has had the temerity to attack you. “This is what you see from Mr Stokes… everyone except him wanted to stop. Mr Ali moved away, Mr Hales was saying ‘Stokes, Stokes, that’s enough’, and tried to get hold of him on two occasions to stop the violence. “This is retaliation, retribution, not self-defence.” The court heard that Hale said to Stokes “f***you”. Stokes then knocked him out and CCTV shows Hale on his back.  Mr Corsellis said: “[Stokes] then turned to Mr Ali who had no weapon on him, on to the second assault on the second man.” The court heard that Hale staggered to his feet, ran around the corner and levered a metal bar from a road sign, before racing back to the brawl, although it appears he never used it. Ali and Hale, both from Bristol, were treated in hospital. Hale had a 1.5-inch cut on his forehead. Stokes, from Castle Eden, Co Durham, had no obvious injuries except for a swollen hand. Following his arrest at the scene, Stokes said he acted in the way he did “because he was abusing my two friends for being gay”.

title: how dads picture perfect life
story: NewsHow dad's picture-perfect life in £400,000 home hid his horrific abuse and murder of adopted baby daughterMatthew Scully-Hicks, 32, violently shook 18-month-old Elsie and threw her to the floor at their home in Cardiff, Wales - the little girl died four days laterShare&nbspByJason Evans14:58, 6 AUG 2018Updated22:43, 6 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 'Jekyll and Hyde' dad's picture-perfect life in a &pound400,000 home hid his horrific abuse and murder of his adopted baby girl. Matthew Scully-Hicks, 32, began adoption proceedings of daughter Elsie several years ago, along with his husband, Craig. A stay-at-home father, he went on to portray himself as the perfect parent, telling family and friends how in love he was with little Elsie. Pictures showed him playing the doting dad, cuddling, playing and waving with the youngster, with a huge smile on his face. Neighbours, friends and colleagues spoke warmly of Matthew, who appeared to be part of the very model of a modern, happy family. While Craig would go to work, he looked after their princess at their four-bedroom home in an upmarket area in Wales. But looks can be deceiving, Wales Online reports.  Just weeks after the formal adoption of Elsie went through, the baby was dead, murdered by father Matthew at just 18 months old. The part-time fitness instructor had completed the rigorous adoption process without a hitch, and without any concerns being raised. It looked like he, with Craig, could give Elsie the new start she needed. When the little girl was taken to hospital over the months before her death with injuries, medical staff accepted the explanations offered. However, there was something sinister and sad going on. Unable to cope with the demands of parenthood, 32-year-old Matthew was physically abusing his little daughter under the noses of professionals, family, friends, and even his husband. This was not a case where a family went under the radar of those in authority - they received regular visits from staff during the adoption process, health visitors would later call as they do with any new family, and medical staff would see Elsie at hospital.  But Matthew's subsequent trial, and a review by social services, would lay bare the terrible details of his daughter's short life. The painful reality is that the abuse of Elsie was hidden in plain sight. The lives of Elsie and Matthew began in very different places. She was taken into care shortly after birth because of concerns about her mother's drug use, while he was born into and grew up in a loving family. Without adoption, their lives would never have crossed. Elsie was placed with the couple in September 2015, and six months later the newly-formed family moved to a home in the upmarket Cardiff suburb of Llandaff. Matthew's husband, Craig, described how he had hoped to adopt a “Daddy’s little princess” and said Elsie was “great” apart from sleeping and at meal times. Elsie was physically tiny and delicate but had a “brash and bouncy” personality, he would later tell Cardiff Crown Court. A health visitor described her as “a very happy, smiley child” and said she was loving life, she was lovely - smiles all round.  Vivian Cownie, a former colleague of Matthew, would later describe him as a very proud father, a caring and loving father who would do anything for his child. On November 5 that year, Elsie suffered a leg injury, the first in a series of injuries she was to sustain. The infant was X-rayed on November 12 at the Cardiff and Vale University Health Board Trauma and Orthopaedics Clinic and found to have broken her right tibia above her ankle. In fact, she had also suffered a second fracture of the leg - above her right knee - but that was not picked up until after her death. Matthew claimed he had been looking after her alone when he saw her fall while standing at an activity table in the kitchen. He claimed at various times that she may have fallen from standing or while pushing a walker, twisting her leg in the process. During his trial he would say that perhaps his daughter had been suffering from Vitamin D deficiency, or rickets, which could have made her more likely to suffer fractures.  A medical expert would tell the jury that he had never seen fractures of both bones like the ones suffered by Elsie in a child of her age, adding: “I have seen them in adults in more major traumas such as car accidents or falls from height.” Just a month after the leg fractures, Elsie suffered a horrific bruise to her face - a health visitor advised Matthew to seek medial treatment for the injury but he did not. Matthew claimed Elsie was pulling herself up on a toy kitchen, holding on to the doors when they opened and “she literally went face first down towards the edge” of the unit. The injury happened at the same time as an adoption review and Elsie was seen by her social worker, an adoption social worker and an independent reviewing officer - but the presence of the bruise was not recorded. Five days later, a health professional also saw the bruise but did pass on the information. By January 18, little Elsie had another bruise on her face, which again went unchecked by medics. But on March 10, 2016, Matthew did call for help - he rang 999 and said daughter had fallen down the stairs at their Wellwright Road home.  He told the call-handler she had vomited a number of times, and was now unresponsive. Elsie was rushed to hospital where her injuries were noted as being consistent with such a fall, and she was allowed home after four hours’ observation. Only one person knows precisely how the toddler came by those injuries over the months in her new home. To the outside world, Matthew presented as a loving and proud stay-at-home dad, and it seems no alarm bells were heard by those in a position to intervene. But in text messages to his husband, who was spending much of his time working away from home, he described Elsie as Satan dressed up in a Baby grow, a psycho and the exorcist. On May 12, 2016, Elsie was legally adopted by Craig and Matthew Scully-Hicks. The family was now formally complete. On May 25, Matthew took Elsie shopping for clothes to wear at a party to celebrate her adoption - he sent pictures of outfits at Marks &amp Spencer to his husband, and bought one for her to wear.  But at 6.18pm that same day, he made a 999 call saying his daughter had collapsed. He told the operator: I was just changing my daughter for bed and she went all floppy and limp. When police and paramedics arrived at their home at 6.26pm, the 18-month-old was not breathing and was in cardiac arrest. Matthew claimed he had changed Elsie’s nappy on the rug in the living room, and had then taken her clothes and dirty nappy away - when he returned two or three minutes later, she was on the floor but was not breathing or moving. Elsie died in the University Hospital of Wales four days later. Tests revealed she had suffered three separate areas of bleeding on her brain, retinal bleeding, a skull fracture, and three broken ribs. South Wales Police launched an investigation. The truth of what happened to Elsie emerged during the subsequent four-week murder trial at Cardiff Crown Court. Matthew had murdered her, had assaulted and abused his daughter for seven months before violently shaking her and causing her catastrophic injury.  The jurors heard contrasting evidence of the fitness instructor’s warm, loving nature but also of the frustrated, angry tone of his text messages to his husband, and how he would scream at Elsie. They were also presented with a wealth of medical evidence. During the trial, they heard from consultant paediatrician Stephen Rose, who said it was likely that Elsie Scully-Hicks had been shaken violently and that her head had been rocked backwards and forwards so that her head was flexed down on to her chest and flexed backwards. He told the jury: This mechanism would then cause the subdural bleeding, or the bleeds around the brain, and the retinal haemorrhages and also it would cause her to stop breathing. Referring to the toddler's skull fracture, he said: There must have been a cause of the fracture skull fractures don’t occur spontaneously and so the only mechanism for a skull fracture is if there was a blow to the head, either during the shaking injury which culminated in Elsie being thrown against a hard floor, or possibly her head being knocked against a wall.  After four days of deliberations, the jury returned its verdict - Matthew was guilty of murdering his daughter. The defendant - who was dubbed a 'Jekyll and Hyde' character by a family court judge - was subsequently sentenced to life in prison. He must serve a minimum term of 18 years behind bars. Sentencing Matthew, Mrs Justice Davies described Elsie as a young, vulnerable and defenceless child whom the defendant had previously injured. She said: In deliberately inflicting serious injuries upon your 18-month-old adoptive daughter you abused the trust which had been placed in you as Elsie’s adoptive father. It was a gross abuse of that trust. It was an abuse of the responsibility which had been placed upon you as her adoptive father to protect and care for this young, vulnerable and defenceless child. Your actions in killing Elsie have devastated three families – the birth family of Elsie, the family you had sought to build with Craig Scully-Hicks and your own birth family. You were living in comfortable social circumstances with the close support of professional agencies, your husband and wider family.  To those who saw you regularly, be it healthcare professionals, social workers or friends and family you were a loving and caring father. She added: To no one, not even your husband, did you have the courage to speak of your difficulties. You put your own self-interest before that of the young child you had been entrusted to protect. In separate family court proceedings conducted before the trial but only reveled afterwards, it emerged that a judge had completely exonerated Matthew's husband Craig of any failure to protect Elsie. Speaking after the trial, Elsie’s birth grandmother, Sian O’Brien, revealed the anguish of the family. She accepted that at the time of giving birth, her daughter was living a chaotic lifestyle and was not in a position to care for her baby. But she said the family continued to have contact with the child - originally named Shayla O'Brien - while she was in the care of the foster family. And she said that in January 2015 she had started proceedings in the family court to become her legal . The grandmother said: We all continue to fight on even though every day we are numb with pain and hurt deep in the knowledge that Shayla was loved unconditionally by us all as a family and knowing that had she not been taken away from us, she would still be alive today.  Despite this decision and Shayla being in foster care, we as a family were still able to have weekly contact with her and we saw her without fail at every opportunity. In August 2015, out of nowhere, we were told by social services that we had to go and see Shayla as soon as possible and say goodbye for the final time as a suitable adoptive family had been found for her. This was completely devastating for us all. She added: A person who had been deemed by the authorities to be a fit and proper person to bring up my granddaughter was responsible for her death, and they took her from me telling me I would be unable to cope. Following the death of Elsie, a child practice review undertaken by Cardiff and Vale Regional Child Safeguarding Board found professionals saw the youngster's injuries in isolation, lacked professional curiosity and accepted the explanations given by Matthew. The report said that Matthew and his partner presented as a well-educated and articulate couple and very positive parents for this child. As a result, there was a lack of professional curiosity regarding the child’s experiences and injuries. The report said the professionals involved in the case viewed the adoptive placement as being very successful, and it criticised the recording of incidents and communication between agencies claiming no one agency held all the relevant information on this child.

story: NewsKFC gravy gives boy, 10, serious burns after he spilled it on his legKyle Core was left a serious burn from the gravy bought from a KFC store in HuddersfieldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRobert Sutcliffe23:13, 6 AUG 2018NewsJoanne Conway, her son Kyle and his dad David CoreGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has demanded restaurant chain KFC lower the temperature of its famous gravy after her son suffered serious burns when some of it spilled onto his leg.
